description:
Things bad companies say to their employees.    If you're wondering if you're interviewing for or working in a toxic workplace, here's some things to look for.   Toxic companies tend to say these 9 things.   

Want weekly actionable tips on how to act like the CEO of your career?  Join my FREE newsletter here:  https://alifeafterlayoff.ck.page/90f4...


0:00 - intro 
1:07 - we work hard play harder
2:26 - we are a family
3:22 - we'll promote you later
4:15 - you're replaceable 
5:08 - we wear lots of hats
5:34 - we are in startup mode
5:54 - we only hire rockstars
6:14- we're always hiring
7:40 - we have foosball
8:29 - if you need help

_____________________________________________________________
Get more FREE career resources at https://www.alifeafterlayoff.com/

Need personalized help with your job search?   https://www.alifeafterlayoff.com/care...

INTERVIEW TRAINING: 

Have a BIG INTERVIEW coming up and want to be fully prepared?   Check out the 48-hour Interview Crash Course!  https://a-life-after-layoff.teachable.com/p/the-48-hour-interview-crash-course

Learn to navigate and master the entire job search process from application to offer with The Ultimate Job Seeker Bootcamp:  
https://a-life-after-layoff.teachable.com/p/the-ultimate-layoff-bootcamp

RESUME TRAINING:
 
Learn how to write a professional quality resume!  Check out 🚀 Resume Rocketfuel 🚀
https://a-life-after-layoff.teachable.com/p/resumerocketfuel

LINKEDIN TRAINING:

Learn how to skip the recruiter by Unlocking LinkedIn:  https://a-life-after-layoff.teachable.com/p/unlocking-linkedin
_______________________________________________
I've got merch!!   Get your witty work mugs here!    
https://a-life-after-layoff.creator-s...

Gear I use to make my videos:

Zoom Audio Recorder:   https://rstyle.me/+us_yPFbfd_ALGlHiNi...
Rode Mic:   https://rstyle.me/+us_yPFbfd_ALGlHiNi...
Mic Preamp booster:  https://rstyle.me/+A_FyK8YyEzy-yboqHS...
Light Stands for desk:   https://rstyle.me/+EDESBbDgoiFXdVeFIr...
Video lighting:  https://rstyle.me/+Svs8aRg7j1rwFH2geo...      (I have 4 of these)
Camera (coming soon)  
_____________________________________________________
 
Are you struggling with your job search?   Applying for job after job and not getting any interviews?   Perhaps you’ve got a few interviews but always seem to get passed over for the job?   Or maybe you’re not satisfied with your current career and want a change.  Well, you’ve come to the right place.   
 
As a corporate recruiter with over 20 years of experience hiring thousands of employees at all levels into major corporations, I’m going to spill the beans on how to get noticed by recruiters, start getting more interviews, navigate through each step of the hiring process, and ultimately land the dream job you deserve.   
 
But that’s not all - I firmly believe that to truly experience career success, you need to think bigger.   Multiple streams of income and budgeting are crucial to forming a layoff-free lifestyle and helping you achieve your goals.    
 
If these are things you’re struggling with, that’s what I specialize in.   I’ve got a website called A Life After Layoff.   It’s loaded with tips and tricks for getting noticed, interviewed, and hired by your dream company.    Make sure you check it out!   
 
I’ve got weekly videos coming at you, so make sure to subscribe.   You won’t want to miss a post.   Join me as we explore these things, all from an insider’s perspective!   
____________________________________________________________________
💥 Sign up for my FREE 5-Day Bootcamp for Job Seekers:  https://alifeafterlayoff.ck.page/7735...
______________________________________________________________________
👉  Join my network! 
➤  Facebook Community:   https://www.facebook.com/alifeafterla...
➤  Linkedin Community:   https://www.linkedin.com/company/a-li...
➤  Tik Tok Community:  https://www.tiktok.com/@alifeafterlay...
👉 Connect with Me on LinkedIn:  https://www.linkedin.com/in/bryan-cre...

Follow our other channel!     

 / @myracreely

fulltitle: 9 Things Bad Companies Say To Their Employees - Toxic Workplace Signs

comments.text: Well, at least if a company says that one is replaceable it's being honest.
comments.author: @arthurvassy7499

comments.text: I just left a company actually that was a "family" atmosphere. I graduated college in 2019 right before the pandemic so couldnt find a job for almost a year because of covid. So frankly at the time I was desperate. I was told during the interview that they were SPECIFICALLY looking for people with geology degrees, which was my degree. I moved from Texas, all the way to indiana for this job, with no relocation assistence i might add. They werent going to hire me initally becuse i needed "too long to move there" i dont think 4 weeks is tol much to ask to move halfway across the country. My boss said "if you can get here in 2 weeks you have the job" so i packed up and moved. NOT A SINGLE PERSON they hired in my position even remotelay had a degree, even though it said it was tequired for the position and i was making 18 an hour just like people woth no degree, had a boss that yelled and cussed at me all the time when we messed up and constantly walked on eggshells. Anyway a whole situation with me and my boss ensued, basically he was homophobic and i knew he was because i heard him say it begore to other people putsode of work. He knew i was gay and made my life a living hell because of it. All the sudden when he found out i was put on a performance improvement plan, never got a verbal warning, neber got written up, just automatic PIP. Any way i left. Now im workingnfor a new company in Arizona rhat i LOVE and that boss ended up getting fired because i called HR on him. Oh sweet Karma.
comments.author: @levistokes3960

comments.text: Family owned business talks about promotion  opportunity.   Ya, ok right after all your kids.
comments.author: @BirdDogey1

comments.text: I worked at a company that my team told management that the workload is too high and the next meeting one of them had made a spreadsheet (missing many steps) which said that we should have 6 spare hours a week. Considering we were all doing unpaid overtime to complete the work, it was massively insulting.
comments.author: @TheMattew777

comments.text: "We only hire rockstars" I see this a lot in the insurance world. That is typically impromptu commission only high turnover language. Sell to your friends and family kind of deal. Nothing wrong with commission only but professional insurance firms don't talk like that, because they are professional ...
comments.author: @user-sp7wy2vk7l

comments.text: Just had DEI training. Didn't know it was bigotry. And it most definitely is. Toxic.
comments.author: @HarpuaPoster-ng9pl

comments.text: Had an office manager once who referred to herself as "Mama" and the firm's managing partner as "Daddy." She thought it was cute or something 🤢
comments.author: @JP-ve7or

comments.text: I remember a guy giving a presentation at Uni one time, at the political sector of the profession we were studying for, basically telling us we shouldn't consider what the job can offer us, but what we can offer the job. Sure, that's something you should consider when talking to a potential employer, but it shouldn't be your entire worldview when it comes to work.
comments.author: @AllHailMe12431

comments.text: How about management by fear as a motivator?  Constantly repeating "if we lose clients we're going to have to start cutting jobs."
comments.author: @Wahinies

comments.text: "We wouldnt hire someone like you.  We're getting rid of old people like you!"
comments.author: @christineribone9351

comments.text: Thank you for this. So many of these practices are normalized when they shouldn't be.
comments.author: @shereemoskow1961

comments.text:
We'll promote you later

Had exactly this happen to me. Years ago I took a job that was $1 less than my previous job but I was promised that after 3 months probation I would get a raise. Within in 2 weeks of starting the guy who hired me (the warehouse manager) left.
comments.author: @causerDAguv

comments.text: A customer asked me "Do you work here?" No", I replied and then I added "I've never worked a day in my life".. My employer overheard us and said "He's certainly not exaggerating about that". So, naturally I continued on with "And I don't get paid enough to lie very well either, after all, anything less than $1000 a week is just a hobby.nowadays". It was an interesting 25 years.
comments.author: @arthurleblanc7272

comments.text: I don’t need foosball, I need money 💵
comments.author: @JennX1791

comments.text: Ha! the foosball table! the most toxic and damaging workplace I was at had one! Someone there made a joke that you don't start there with a mental illness you'd be leaving with one and it was sadly true.
comments.author: @jessdavis4808

comments.text: I think i know which airline you are talking about
comments.author: @duyksl1667

comments.text: Opinionated Remarks 😅
comments.author: @lucasjohnstone1272

comments.text: Dude I work at sweetwater and 3 maybe 4 out of the 9 things have been said in one interview☠️
comments.author: @omnifluxx9230

comments.text: My coworkers are not my family. They are not my friends. I don’t actually want to spend time with these people
comments.author: @jgamer2228

comments.text: Assume everything that your company tells you is a lie.
comments.author: @Kenjiro5775

comments.text:
Oddest red flag I've ever had was a place where the interview went pretty well, I liked the person doing the interview, the work was interesting.  But being developers we started bouncing dev jokes off of each other.  So then he looks around, checks that nobody is in the hallway, and pulls out a photocopied sheet of nothing but the most G rated dev and office humor cartoons you could ever find.  Turns out the company had strict rules about not posting anything not work related on cube walls and employees were not supposed to use the photocopier for personal material - not even on sheet apparently.  So he had to keep it in a desk drawer to not get into trouble.  Yeah, not the place for me.

But the best place I worked for did have a Foosball table, and a pinball machine, and a MAME arcade game.  And they didn't frown at you of you took a break to use them.  Was a great place until it was sold, then it turned into another pile of corporate sludge.
comments.author: @xlerb2286

comments.text: Corporate greed low life managers welcome to America
comments.author: @KevinBetts-ud2lq

comments.text:
Employer to employee: You are replaceable. 
Employee to employer: It's a two-way street, and you are just as replaceable.
comments.author: @semaxwell1

comments.text: My family don't have to pay me to hang around with them. 🚩
comments.author: @NorX50

comments.text:
"We have High Expectations from you". The Boss Started pitching that he was open to calls 24/7 & how he started the company hustling long hours sleeping on the office couch. His visionary scheme of things & people working during the weekends without being told.
Man was I into another Joyride.
comments.author: @viclazarus5357

comments.text: Leave
comments.author: @Joshdifferent

comments.text:
We are being told that "they" will buy "us" a couple of sofas for the break room, but first "we" have to learn to keep the break room tidier.
We still don't have our sofa and we don't have the "right" to use the managers' toilet either!
comments.author: @carlduffin

comments.text: does red flags remind me of USPS
comments.author: @joeljimenez805

comments.text: "We are family" or "We are a community" LMAO
comments.author: @Joser167

comments.text: I feel like this guy has the most authentic and honest eyelids ever.
comments.author: @handymanr4729

comments.text:
Another red flag - companies that misrepresent jobs as “hybrid” or “remote” when they aren’t. I just did a phone screen for one where “Hybrid” was four days on site and one day off. That’s not a hybrid job. That’s a concession.

Another is a “remote” job where you have to live in a certain area (specifically, near one of their facilities.) There’s nothing wrong with stating that you’re required to be onsite on occasion. But that is a Hybrid job, not a remote job. To say its remote is misleading.  A remote job means it can be done anywhere. Consider it a red flag if the job title says Remote, but in the description it requires some on site time. It’s a bait and switch (and they can also convert the job to on site at some point.)

In the mode of “being the CEO of your career”  - I go in stating I’m looking for 100% remote. I also ask about what there hybrid arrangement is. In yesterday’s interview, I said “ I realize that a hybrid role means different things in different companies. What arrangement do you have at <company>. If they hem and haw, it’s a misrepresentation.
comments.author: @cvermette

comments.text: Amazon showed me this amazing break room with a Foosball table that I never saw again as an employee.
comments.author: @cloudstrife6435

comments.text: “We have beer bashes on Friday afternoon.” Happened several times. Irresponsible on a number of levels.
comments.author: @cvermette

comments.text: "We hire rockstars" yeah, right! Turn up in jeans with a guitar and see how quick you end up being seen by HR 😂
comments.author: @bigkevonbass

comments.text:
"We're like a family here"

So if two coworkers are dating, doesn't that technically mean they are "keeping it in the family?" 🤢🤮
comments.author: @scootza1

comments.text:
Agreed! Excellent advice for people who have little career/life experience. Insightful! 

When given the chance to ask questions at the end of the interview, I like to ask how they plan to evaluate me and what the criteria is. I have noticed that if a recruiter or manager doesn't know how a prospective employee will be evaluated if hired, or when they plan to evaluate someone, they have NEVER thought beyond just hiring that person. Career growth has never entered their minds. That likely means they have no managerial experience or do not value you or this position. That has been a red flag I wish I paid more attention to at the time.
comments.author: @Robginski

comments.text: It's funny (or kind of sad) but being in a relationship with a covert narcissist is a similar experience.

comments.text: Came here to check if 'what my boss said to me' is listen which isn't.. well I'm a student and did nothing but a recommendation for better Workflow and Bossy Boss yelled at me "you gonna get fired if you don't do what I say" 😂 so I replied"no you won't because I volunterly quit" 😅

comments.text: Oh my god, about half of these apply to the Air Force: "Work hard, play hard", "we're like a family", "we wear lots of hats", "you're replaceable". I'm so glad that I can retire in 21 months!

comments.text:
"Always hiring" in my line of work is mostly from lazy slackers who don't want even want to do a baby's job. Much less even show up.
Sometimes I'm asked to do these tasks and I'm absolutely delighted to do it. Lower workers see me and are like wtf? lol 
Compared to what I do, it's like break time to me.

comments.text: The last company I worked at literally had all of these signs

comments.text: I work a government position and I noticed my employer do some crappy things. In order to get promoted in my department you have to go on call and they keep promising overtime bonus pay. I don't want to give more time to the job but an associate tried it. He don't make better pay and can't leave the city when on call. He made more working a second job vs the on call and they claim he can't leave on call.
comments.author: @Dtgray12

comments.text: McDonald's is my family. I love my career and regard all my staff as family. I think because I'm a manager who never had that environment and want others to feel welcomed
comments.author: @anthonylevi

comments.text:
"We want a good kid" 
translation:we want someone who will do anything we tell him to do with the least amount of money
comments.author: @giannis9370

comments.text: And the "kid" reference is "lots of energy cuz we're gonna run you ragged"!
comments.author: @kendallevans4079

comments.text:
So I only have one question:
Is there ANY employer  that does not fall foul of at least ONE  of these ?
My last 4 decades have been spent in SME / Corporate, and EVERY SINGLE ONE has exhibited at least ONE of these 'characteristics'.
if you want to get PAID what you are worth, start YOUR OWN Company, and pay others to mop up the 'smaller stuff'. Of course, YOU could lose YOUR house, shirt and family in the process.
comments.author: @almostbutnotentirelyunreas166

comments.text: all i can say, american employees are high miantenance and hard to manage
comments.author: @mankitwong4165

comments.text: mk North America, i think they said all these things. So happy to be out of there
comments.author: @davecalvo6418

comments.text:
We prioritize DEI and ESG above all.
What are your pronouns?
We emphasize representation.
Im gay, if i hear crap like the above I know im dealing with a company that worry’s about twitter than reality.
comments.author: @mikewaterfield3599

comments.text: Work hard, play hard. Rockstars lol. I’m looking at you Rocket Mortgage and United Wholesale Mortgage
comments.author: @thekingoftown07

comments.text: Self-starter, highly motivated candidate...
comments.author: @cturdo

comments.text: The company I was with showed me how they don’t value loyalty. Toxic work environment for sure. They fired me for doing the work of three people and paid me for less than one. Never again. I’m fifty and have to start over unfortunately
comments.author: @markrick2195

comments.text: AI is going to take every non hands on production job. Chatgbt could already take HR and management roles. I could fill in my development plan with AI and it'll be more comprehensive than I could ever make it.
comments.author: @mattpascoeiow

comments.text:
I read a job posting for a small company that seemed to fit my skills perfectly until I got to the last data point which said "Must know how to take a joke."
It made me think that they are the kind of people who play mean-spirited pranks on each other lol I didn't even bother to apply.
comments.author: @CourtneyClemons

comments.text: Sometimes I look at Germany and think could America be better if it was burnt down?
comments.author: @nickjohnson3619

comments.text:
I've been through most of these over my 35+ years in software.  Only 2 companies were truly "family" and "work hard, play hard".  They treated employees well and rewarded us well for working our asses off, and if you needed time to recoup you got it.  These were successful companies, and that was the problem itself.  When push came to shove they sold themselves to bigger competitors, and the new companies shit all over everyone.  I did get some payoff on both merger/acquisitions.  

But the new owners really turned the heat up and expected us to take shit and just live with it.  The turnover got bad, people left in waves.  When I left I was asked why I was leaving and I told them that the place had changed, wasn't what I joined for and needed to do something else.  I got the "we really need you" and "we've been loyal to you" guilt trips.  I just left it alone, but wanted to tell them they treated me and a lot of other people like cogs in the machine and treated us like shit.

I learned that loyalty is to yourself and your family (your real family) first and foremost.  Take as much as you can get (money & benefits) and do just enough to keep things on an even keel.  Because the second you give more, they will take more, and keep expecting more without giving anything back.  

It's not personal, just business.
comments.author: @calkelpdiver

comments.text:
I'd like to add a few things to this from my own observations. 

1) Don't work for crazy. If you hear that your boss believes in some hollow moon lizard people stuff, or the illuminati really killed JFK, I would steer clear from them because delusion has a way of infecting the rest of their thoughts. I'd also avoid people who are overly religious, and to clarify on that,  one of my previous bosses refused to let "Highway to Hell" be played on the radio in her presence. That was weird, yes, but not as weird as her accusing me of summoning demons into her house and presenting a picture of "orbing" in her living room to management to justify her claims. Bottom line, don't work for the delusional. 

2) The nanosecond they start playing games with your payroll, you need to be out that door. Even if they explain that times are tough and they'll "pay you the rest later", I have rarely seen this to be the case. People who owe you money tend to find reasons to dislike you, and you might find yourself being "let go" for "unsatisfactory performance" because your boss owes you money. I got ripped off for my last 2 weeks of pay and the vacation time I had accumulated at my last job, but that place was so toxic I just decided to write it off as a loss rather than fight for it. Fuck those guys.
comments.author: @ZeraSeraphim

comments.text:
Ironically, when I used to be in an actual cult, they always told us we were family, and they had a foosball table.  I love studying cults, and one of the things about religious cults is that they are far less about dressing up in dark robes and having weird ceremonies, and more about using your religious faith to have you provide them with free or reduced cost labor, so that they can maximize profits for the heads of the church.  It isn't all that strange to me that some corporations try to come into the other way, by pretending to be businesses with religious values, instead of being a religion that acts like a business, like you normally find in cults.

It is okay to have faith, but your work life and your spiritual life should be two entirely different things, unless you are a preacher, and even then you should keep a wall between your spiritual side and your business side if you want your church to be a healthy and safe space for others.

comments.text: I'm not fully on board with the layoff conclusion. Look into just what "layoff" looks like in detail - some (definitely not all) companies put money into a supplemental unemployment benefit (SUB) fund. Employees laid off are often paid from that fund based on factors like years of service. And yes, they recall employees when the business environment improves. Sometimes this is just part of a cyclical business environment. The right questions need to be asked during the interview process to make sure one can plan for and handle such cycles.

comments.text:
"The [company name] Family" -- usually all about the company owner's family, not yours. Not the worst I worked for, but definitely a downside. 

"Always Hiring" -- Definitely a reason for it. Some companies have a way of making what should be a normal, decent job suck.

"Fast-Paced" -- You really need to be an Olympic athlete to be really good at this job. 

Layoffs -- I grew up in Washington state and got an electronics degree. Why do I not work for Boeing? Because when I was a kid I saw on the news they were laying off every other year. Smart youth pay attention to this stuff.

Temp-To-Hire -- We'll not interview anyone, we'll just onboard 30 applicants a pay period under impossible conditions and hire the one person that actually cuts the mustard. By odds alone, this usually is a bad experience for the recruit.

I had one disaster, a temp-to-hire warehouse job. They hired so many they ran out of box cutters before I could get one and then accused me of stealing when I asked for one the next day. I should have walked out then and there. I have not spent a single penny in their stores since for over fifteen years.

There are also things a company that tries can do to reduce turnover. This is important too. There are jobs I would have never left if:
1. I could have just made another $200-$300 a month. Just to keep my house (already probably the cheapest in town) from completely falling apart. 
2. If they could have kept overtime under control. My family needs me too. Especially when a pandemic turns the world upside down.
3. If the schedule weren't so random. I could have gotten a second job for badly needed income. 
4. If the manager was good leadership. Good managers coach and empower, they don't berate and belittle. Most managers are ok, but I've encountered a small number who were bad enough to motivate a job change.

Companies should also remember that employees have families. Especially in a small town, those families could be a future source for needed employees. But there are companies that I will not work for after the way they treated my wife, and there are companies my kids will not work for after seeing my experience.
comments.author: @310McQueen

comments.text: The medical field is a pretty toxic place to work. It revolves around giving idiots (most patients are idiots) everything they ask for, and encouraging them to abuse nursing staff when they perceive (incorrectly) that a mistake has been made. They're led to believe that nurses are food service and hospitality workers rather than science and tech professionals. The whole game revolves around tricking these idiots into giving the big wigs a high survey score so they can make more money from Medicare and Medicaid.
comments.author: @americandissident9062

comments.text:
I work in the medical field as a bachelor level RN.

"We work hard, we play hard" usually means the environment is extremely fast paced, corners sometimes have to be cut, we are taking risks we probably shouldn't be taking, and then most likely will have a clique of people who will go to bars and get drunk every weekend, sometimes might fuck each other, and you have to do that too if you want to fit in and get a little bit of help during your awful shifts.

"We are a family" is basically saying that our scheduling and shift hours are going to suck, or they're going to need scheduling holes filled and you're going to be expected to do that.

"We will promote you later" is not often stated. RNs don't have a lot of room for promotion.

"You are replaceable" isn't heard all the time in my field, at least not lately. There is a lack of nurses who want to do bedside care. Patients are awful and treat nurses poorly, and so we are always hearing about this nursing shortage in the US. Except there is not a nurse shortage. Just a nurse shortage at the patient bedside. Nurses are getting their bachelor and master degrees and moving into lobbying, research, management, quality, education, etc. They're leaving the patient bedside because patients are horrible. So nurses know damn well we are hard to replace at the bedside.

"We wear many hats" means that when housekeeping isn't there, the nurse will clean it. If phlebotomy isn't there, the nurse will draw the blood. If a tech isn't there, the nurse will do the tech's job. If registration isn't there, the nurse will sign the patient in. Etc. The nurse will always be expected to pick up the slack and this will not be considered when doing raises.
comments.author: @americandissident9062

comments.text:
Over 10 years ago I worked for a small company for 7 months. I left on good terms to pursue another opportunity. The owner  kept in touch saying there would always be a job there for me. A couple of years later they were bought out by a venture capital company. The owner called to tell me about it and how there was now more opportunity and better pay, and would I like to come back, which I did.
However, new management was in place, and the owner was due to leave having been bought out. The new manager didn't like me. Combination of suspicion and my questions regarding their approach. After 6 months I was called into the Managing Directors office. Also there was the original owner. I merely assumed it was about some aspect of the work.  Straight away the MD said (Ican't remeber the exact words due to shock) 
"There isn't a place a for you here. If you want to keep your reputation intact you won't dig your heels in. We need to plan your exit". He and the original owner (who had persuaded me to give up a secure  job to come back) then proceeded to tell me I wasn't qualified or experienced for the job. The previous owner was going along with it to protect his payout. The new manager who didn't like me, didnt even have the guts to join the meeting and say anything to my face.
To cut to the chase I had to accept a redundancy which was rushed through within a week. This created an atmosphere of fear, and nobody was prepared to put their head above the trench and give me covering fire.
Whenever I speak to a manager now, I discreetly run the voice recorder on my phone.
comments.author: @MrAlwaysBlue

comments.text:
Dear Young Adults:  over many decades, I have come to realize that in general, the older folks use the younger folks for their own personal gain, usually by taking advantage of the ignorance of younger folks.  Most folks in their twenties have not yet started their own families, and so they still at some level miss the families that raised them (admit it), particularly if they have moved away from them (even if they left a rotten family, they just miss the idea of a good family).  So when a company comes along and promises to be their proxy family, such a company is taking unrighteous advantage of a very natural need in those younger adults.  Remember:  it is great to find fulfillment at a job, but 99% of people who work never do so.  So do not look for it there.  And here is the important thing:  that is not a bad thing (so do not act as if the company denied you something that it owed you).  A job is just a paycheck machine:  the means by which you earn the money to pay for building a hopefully fulfilling life outside of work.  At work, people with whom you would never otherwise associate, meet and tolerate each other's existence long enough to extract a paycheck from the situation.  Do your best to play the game at work (and keep that paycheck), but never let the game play you.  And when a time comes to make a move, then make sure that every move is a step forward and upward.  If there are no opportunities at the moment, then bide your time, keep looking, but continue to earn that paycheck.  Seek fulfillment in your personal lives.  Give your loyalty to people (family and friends), not to organizations.

Oh yeah, P.S.:  hey man, get rid of that movie make-up.  Be real.
comments.author: @notsure1277

comments.text: Sure there's always jargon flying fast and furious during interviews, but I think by now all employers and employees understand each other and know the game or "dance" of the employer/employee relationship.  We're already in the second generation of employees who have been conditioned all their lives to expect to jump ship every few years between employers, and employers expect that. In return, employees expect that they can be fired ("laid off") at any given moment for reasons unrelated to their own performance and qualities. So all the trappings of the corporate environment become meaningless in terms of happy employment. For instance, I work for the most touchy/feely corporate employer you can imagine, and yet layoffs happen without much fanfare on a periodic basis.
comments.author: @richatlarge462

comments.text:

"No, not really."

comments.text:
Other red flag terminologies and clues.

1. Flexible attitude required'  Use a lot by temping agencies. All it means is that your job description for which you are meant to be taking on, is - for you as a temp - a loosely defined set of tasks and most of the time your permanent colleagues will substitute all their unpleasant, boring jobs for the more interested ones you would otherwise be doing. 

2. 'We're a friendly workplace.'  Nope. You will be a dolphin swimming in shark infested waters. 

3.  'You are the wrong cultural fit'. HR speak for 'we hate you' or 'we don't want minorities on our team, especially older people.

4.  The interviewing panel of pale, male and stales all state that DIE is a core part of their company DNA. When you start, you see the odd token minority dotted around and no minorities at senior level.

comments.text:
Something people don't realize:
After Covid, MOST (not all) Companies are subsidized by the state and Federal Government to take on new hires. They get an allotment to train & maintain hires for at LEAST 6 months....
.
This ALSO requires a certain number of supervisory and managerial positions based on how many entry level positions they submit FOR that subsidy.
.
There are TWO problems with this..... 1st, most of these companies have a fairly brutal turn-over, so every year they can keep re-submitting for the subsidy and it costs them little as most of the hires that quit didn't stay on long enough to qualify for unemployment.
.
2nd, nothing in the agreement says they have to FILL the Supervisory and Managerial positions... In most cases, you can have the offering notice, the Job Title, AND the file number... and the hiring personnel will feign ignorance, or simply claim it's already been filled. It's not in their best interest to hire ANYTHING but entry level meat.
comments.author: @jamesrobinson2086

I made it through a phone screen but turned down the invite for a first interview with Motley Fool way back in 1999 because their recruiter spent more time talking about the couch and ping pong table they had in their office.  Then she asked me, "if you were a tree, which kind of tree would you be."


 I got offers from AOL, a contractor who maintained the SEC's  Edgar database, and another contractor who ran the FAA's corporate networks.  I didn't have time to screw around with that college prep school inanity.  Come join our clubhouse!  It'll be fun and we can all be pals!  Lol.

Years later I delivered food for a restaurant in McLean, Virginia for extra money and delivered to a Palantir office that had a life sized stuffed Wookie and a pool table in the reception area.  I never saw anyone use the table.  In fact, the balls always seemed to be in the same position on the tsble, like someone had staged a table in mid play. But they also had one of those glass block walls separating the lobby from the work area and you could see through the blur that there were coders sitting shoulder to shoulder hacking away at keyboards like a coding mill sweat shop.  The rookie and pool table was simply a recruiting and marketing tool or ploy.  I wonder if it's part of the architectural plans for fitting out all new palantir offices.

comments.text:
I worked in a team of 15 people, that was running several different projects spread out over the employees.
We had just barely enough people to fulfill our workload, and despite my department manager's best efforts, the chief manager refused to hire more people. Basically, when everyone showed up for work, we had just the bare minimum of employees to get everything done. The moment the unthinkable happened, such as someone taking a vacation or became sick, we'd have to spread out people over several positions, otherwise, we'd be unable to fulfill our legal obligations. This of course lead to overtime hours, which would increase the issue: When someone reduces work-hours to decrease his overtime, that'd mean someone else would have to pick up the workload and this would lead to them having overtime.

Again: My department manager tried to get more employees for over a year, the chief manager always sneered at him and said he'll have to make do with what he has, cause the department was "bloated" anyway...

For me personally, that meant that I had to pick up a lot of extra workload in order to keep things running, I essentially ran three different projects at the same time and racked up almost an entire months worth of overtime in a few months.

Eventually, my department manager pulled a few strings and switched to a different department under a different chief manager, ironically, this meant that me and another co-worker were able to also "jump ship" with him.

The chief manager now had to take care of the department himself and despite being down 3 people, he was still adamant about having TOO MANY employees.
Within two weeks of him running the department, 11 of the remaining 12 people quit or decided to quit as soon as they got any other job.

What really pisses me off, is that we managed to get through the pandemic, we were on a course to grow and the chief manager pissed that all away through sheer incompetence. And even though the CEO KNOWS all this, he doesn't fire this massively incompetent buffoon.
So, long story short: I'm now in a new department, it's better than before, but I'll be in the market for a new job somewhere else at some point, given that the CEO is part of the problem.
comments.author: @h.a.9880

comments.text:
Never give a company 100% of your efforts and ideas. Use that on yourself, start a business on it. Fuck them “corporate ethics” on not limiting your employer with your ideas when they only pay you the same from your brilliant ideas? — what do you get out of it? A sense of accomplishment? A promotion that only has a certain salary hike? The ego boost? The status name? Or is it that monthly pizza party the management does to thank their team for their efforts? 

You are making the executives rich, not yourself. Give good ideas enough to keep you hired or at least be skilled enough for them to see you as too valuable to fire. Learn as much and make as much valuable connections and use that to your advantage. Then plan your escape gracefully. Keep your side hustles/ projects on the side and work on that. Learnt it the hard way.

comments.text: I worked for a 3rd party contractor for American Airlines called Envoy Air. I regret giving them my 5 years and herniated disc. We were located in Nashville BNA and we were one of the larger American Hubs, and being that we had more employees then some of the other airports. So instead of American Airlines directly hiring us and having to give us benefits they hired a 3rd party contractor to make more money. We had meetings after meetings trying to become a union like the rest of Americans crew. It was frustrating going to another city, and seeing a American Airlines worker doing the same exact job as you but makes way more and has benefits. We were promised year after year “Next year we’re making you union” just to keep us around. 6 months after Covid hit they had another meeting to see if they would make us a union and it was denied. I quit the next day. Did that make a difference and do they really care, probably not. But I refuse to work for a company like that again. I work for a small privately owned cannabis company and couldn’t be treated better. Older I get the more I despise the wealthy that step on and use normal people to get ahead in life. Sorry for the rant your video just made me remember how shitty they were

comments.text:
Things I've learnt from bad jobs:
 
When it's bad, they say it'll get better and just need to get through this period. That doesn't mean a bad quarter financially, but to do with a context where the work environment has took a turn. They will say it's due to X reason, but in reality that is how the business operate now for the long term. Essentially the reliance on your loyalty to stick it out during the bad times. Like the video says, it's a bad relationship that only seems to care about you when they need you. It's only a faux care and they'll NEVER put their money where their mouth is. FYI, that doesn't mean being economically placated entirely, but improving the culture.

Micro sticks. Each day count how many times you get told you are doing something wrong. If it increases, then count how often this increase lasts for. It may seem minor, but how many times they use stick over carrot shows the business. I once had a job where it got so bad that I'd get 8 emails a day saying I did something wrong. In reality, it was their difficult KPIs that were impossible to achieve. They increased the volume inward work coming, while expecting same level of work and output. It became impossible and something had to give.

Mini promotions. Have they started giving people a title that offers no official purpose, but extract extra work out of people. Similar to the videos point of wearing many hats. It's designed so people don't notice there is a glass ceiling. It makes that person a more company person as they think they're on the pathway of progression.  If it doesn't pay much more and it's not that official then it's fake.
comments.author: @jmmypaddy

comments.text: Yea I worked for a Fortune 500 company (oh screw it, it was Erie Insurance Group. Well that manager retired a couple months before my 2 year mark and guess what, the company had no idea about my upcoming promotion even though the division leader was standing next to the manager when he told me those requirements! I get to my 3 year review and the new manager tells me it’ll be after my 4 year review. So double the time I was originally told. comments.text:
One thing to watch for: interviewer being late to the interview. If it's accidental it's a potential bad sign but if it's deliberate, RUN.

Accidental can be for a number of reasons and not all of them are bad (e.g., manager got stuck in traffic unexpectedly), but deliberate means they don't care about inconveniencing you and/or don't think your time is important. Expect a deliberately late interviewer to be the type that only wants desperate employees, schedules people without regard to their availability, expects people to just drop whatever they're doing and come in if they're short-staffed (and they will always be short-staffed), etc. etc. etc.
comments.author: @OddlyIncredible

comments.text: I run a business and I'm relieved that I don't say any of these. My advice to employees is make yourself valued and you'll be respected and treated well. It's all just a transaction when you boil it down, and it must be mutually beneficial. It's not a family - that suggests some kind of emotional attachment. I do believe in the idea of a team, but only in the sense that communication and cooperation are important.

comments.text:
I’ve heard most of these and you’re right!! The other thing to remember is that the job is there for YOU - not the other way around. If it is not functioning to enhance your life in ways that matter to you, find one that does. 

Having worked for nonprofits for many years, I got used to phrases like “scarce resources”, cross training/multifunctional, “the hardest job you’ll ever love”, work til the job’s done (lots of extra hours with no overtime pay), “the value of the experience we’re giving you is inestimable”, “the work is its own reward “… 🙄

I did like doing nonprofit work but there were definitely pay inequities, unreasonable expectations, undervalued and overworked employees, and in some cases- even unethical things going on. 

Do your homework about the companies and positions you’re interested in working for. There’s plenty of intelligence out there about salaries, company culture, employee reviews of jobs, financial stability of the business, etc. 

It’s not worth it to get into or stay in an environment that won’t add value to your life - or worse, subtract from it.
comments.author: @jhanimalluvr5932

comments.text:
I just started working for a company called HP Peltzer, which is a manufacturing plant that makes the carpeting in Jeep, Ford, Chrystler, and other car companies, with 3 plants located within the U.S.

When I first came in, I did get a similar pitch to "Work hard, play hard," but, There's more Work Hard than play...also, they use the "Work Smarter, Not Harder," pitch, but it's not really a job where "smarts" come into play.

I've now been there for a month, and EVERYDAY, starting from morning 1 (I work 2nd shift, there's no 3rd), I can't move when I first wake up. EVERY joint in my body is in excruciating pain, and everyday I find myself wanting to just leave....ALSO, I started as a TEMP...I know from experience that companies TYPICALLY treat TEMP "employees" like an "oreo cookie" (I know I use a lot of quotes, but there's reason behind it), which means that they layer harsh treatment within "positive reinforcement," and usually one would not see it because the mind is on all that you must accomplish that day, which leads to the next point...unreasonable quotas.

We "must" produce 1,900 pieces of carpeting (different variations) PER DAY, whereas most of the time we barely cover 1,500 to 16,00, ON A GOOD DAY...

This company has a MAJOR turnover rate...in my month of being trhere, I have seen at least 8 people (one left just 2 days ago) in JUST my department, which causes them to USE US (who are left) to "wear different hats," which is superbly the kind of definition this deserves...I have personally worked in multiple departments, one they call "The A Team," where it's CONSTANTLY moving...no room for "loitering," which I don't like to do (I like to move fast), but the reprimanding they do if you slow down is akin to how some Amazon companies treat their employees.

Here's the kiker: this is a factory...I'm an office guy...it was MY decision to "try" other types of work, which I kind of liked (a little), but I chose this type of work THIS TIME because there are no office jobs readily available in my area (at the time), and work is always needed...WHO was it that said life had to be this way in the first place??

Anyways, It's a fast-paced environment (i can handle fast), but CONSTANTLY so, it's stressful; the managers act all "nicey nicey" (in other words, psychological "warfare," which i'm aware of), and then bash on you (rather meanly) when you make a mistake...sometimes saying things that SHOULD be OBVIOUS to everybody, but in reality, it's not.

Everyday since I started, my arms get numb in positions where before they didn't, my toes are aching so that I can't walk straight, my neck, back, shoulders, knees, and other joints ache so that not even Bayer Back and Body helps anymore.




But I needed to work......THAT"S  ALWAYS the catch 22 in all of this.

I want to start my own company, but in this day and age, there's too much to keep up with...for me, at least.
comments.author: @Entolyfik

comments.text: I worked for a multi billion dollar company for 15 years and their excuse for not giving any raises for 11 years was ,"we're restructuring." If you had any complaints with the company, you'd hear, "I have 300 applications sitting on my desk for people who will do the job and not complain." Because of the poor wages they promised for 14 years that they were working on a quarterly bonus across the board. Never happened. They'd tell all the new hires that the company and work was fast paced, fun and exciting. None of that was true. We could earn over 1k a week if we worked hard. You'd have to work 27-7 and still wouldn't get half of that. Then their stoch holders decided to eliminate half the staff and add more and more work per day, but they didn't want you to go over 40 hours a week. It was once a decent company to work for but with investors like Black Rock and Vanguard, they want you to work hard, get paid little and accept the fact that you are their slave. They make billions off the back of hard working underpaid Americans. Sorry about the rambling. After being treated like a number after 15 years, I retired and ran.

comments.text: I'm a biologist who recently quit a job I was in for 1.5 years. Eventually the no.2 person violated animal welfare protocols during trapping/collaring and killed the animal. When I prepared documents to report the incident, I found the data for that animal had been falsified to hide what occurred. So I filed two reports of ethical violations.  The animal death investigation came back guilty, the falsified data investigation came back not guilty because the project was so disorganized that investigators couldn't tell the difference between a mistake and deliberate falsification. My boss was mad at me for reporting the incidents instead of being angry at the the no.2 for committing the violations, and so were all my other coworkers. comments.text:
The worst job I ever had was an equipment operator for a refrigerated warehouse. The warehouse I was working for was going under. So I took whatever I could find before that happened. 
Red flag #1: "Your hours are X to X or until the work is done" The hours were 7pm to 3am. I was already working 2-midnight. I figured I could deal with that. What they don't tell you is the work will never get done. So it's really your hours are until I feel like letting you go. I never left at 3am. it was always 7-7, 7-10, 7-noon.
Red Flag #2: " You are to park a mile down the road and take a bus to the job site". They don't even let their own employees park in their parking lot. That shows you the type of people you will be working with. People who have zero respect for someone else's property. The whole reason that rule was in place is the higher ups got tired of people denting their cars.
I stuck around for 2 months and quit. No other job lined up. I was miserable working there. Found a better job with day hours in like 2 weeks. Don't ever assume you need one particular job.

comments.text:
with my most recent employment that i have been with for a few years, i was brought in during the pandemic to cover for maternity leave. The options for work was literally this company offering a part time position in my field, or night shifts at amazon for slightly higher hourly wage.

looking up this company, major red flags all over it. Family owned and run, recently bought out by international conglomerate. scathing reviews online from former employees at different sites around the country. Thought to myself, okay, its probably going to be shit and im gonna get treated like dirt, but hey thats been the past 3 jobs, and this at least will give me money and a springboard into other jobs.

Went to the interview, head of HR talked the talk, trying to big up the company and gauge me. that part went well enough that he introduced me to the CFO who basically said whats your experience, can you do the job, what salary do i expect. Gave him my expected range, saying i want more but lowest i will go is this. He said fine, i will see you monday. My initial impressions were that my boss was not only down to earth but approachable

I went in and i was right, the place was a mess but by the very nature of who i am and how i work, i picked up and resolved issue after issue such so that within 3 months i was offered full time employment, regardless of the pregnancy cover. I kept at it and was offered a raise in line with the annual increase in wages (as im in the UK, national minimum wage went up at the time, i was given an increase to match this even though i was above the minimum wage). After another 6 months i was offered a promotion to the position that i am now, but it wasnt a position that the company had before and as a trial with my new responsibilities for 3 months i would take on this extra work and see how things worked out. 

after the 3 months, i dropped hints that they need to look at my salary as was promised and they did and i was given an increase to match my extra duties. 

Having now cleared up most of the issues and whilst i still have my extra duties, i can goof around for part of the month and i dont have to work every minute of every day. 

the long and short of it all, if you are willing to put the work in, you may get rewarded. Not every employer will do this, and it is give and take. My employer is far from perfect but tbh they pay me well above what i can get looking for a job elsewhere
comments.author: @primachpepe8597

comments.text: There is a construction company that operates in my area that routinely lays staff off at 89 days of employment. Why do they do that and why is the 89 day termination so important? Well, where I live the law states that after 90 days of employment the employer has to start paying you for statutory holidays and they now have to have a valid reason should they fire you. Under 90 days and they don't have either one of those obligations. comments.text:
The company I work for is a bizarre place. Low pay but decent benefits, the people I work with are amazing, the people a couple 'spots' above them on the food chain? 100% disconnected from the rest of their workers. For example, our COO went in front of the entire company a couple of months ago in a Town Hall style meeting. One of the topics was compensation and I heard something that was so discordant that I actually did a physical double-take. "Money isn't the only form of compensation, and you have to admit we compensate you pretty well here."

My last raise was $0.80/hr.   For those math challenged, my raise didn't even sort of cover the recent inflation and I make LESS now than I did 3 years ago when I was in a lower paying position. It's nuts. I like what I do at the company and the people I work with....but reality is really starting to make itself known. I'm going to be putting up for a raise and at the same time putting out my resume and searching down leads because I've been with the company for years now and I know how this conversation goes. They aren't going to like it this time because what I do there can't be replaced in 2 days with someone completely unfamiliar with the materials.

There are times I feel like I work in a fascist state, because that would be a government 'of the business, for the business, by the business.' and as I look around, I'm not sure what anybody else sees but that sure does describe the current state of things. Unless someone here has recently purchased beneficial legislation from a congress critter? No? Huh.....guess speech isn't so free after all when you attach $ to it. :(

Cheers folks, awesome video!

comments.text:
Ah yes. "We'll promote you later." So when I worked at Game Stop, I was hired on as the 3rd tier management (key holder basically). The store manager quit to spend more time with her family. The district manager told the assistant manager that if he was able to "step up" and hold down the fort and get us through the holiday season (the SM quit in November), he'd be promoted to store manager. The ASM then told me that he wanted me for his assistant manager when that happened (which I was okay with - pay raise and all, plus I'd still get OT).

We worked our asses off that holiday season and I ended up skipping a lot of classes I should have gone to (I was in community college) and ended up having to drop out. At the end of the season? They transferred a store manager from a different store to ours. Naturally, this pissed off the ASM and he ended up transferring to a different store as a result (and later quit).

And that's when I learned not to trust the word of managers - esp when they say we need to "step up" for a period of time until some arbitrary measure can be met. I mean, there was nothing stopping the DM from promoting the ASM to SM right away. It was completely in his power to do that. But he had a specific manager in mind for our store and couldn't justify moving the SM of a much more busy (and profitable) store in December to his higher ups.
comments.author: @SadisticSenpai61

comments.text: Sounds more like he vulgar profanity himself over by promoting you to ASM whilst there was not SM. The Company then decided he is kind of redundant and didn't advance him. comments.text:
As a toddler I was injured in an accident causing my right foot to have a partial amputation and the leg’s growth was retarded for a while thus forcing me to wear a brace and shoe with a lift on it.

I interviewed with a small business owner of a collection agency in St Pete, FL. This owner walks into our meeting, takes a glance at me then notices my leg brace & shoe lift, never once asks me how it happened (a usual query for most). Instead he point blank asks, “Do you think you have the capacity to do this job?” I was confused & asked, “What do you mean?” and he replied, “Your brace? Well, you’re obviously handicapped!” I sat back in the chair a moment then it dawned on me, this moron thought I was 'mentally' handicapped! Because many autistic kids wore leg braces back in the day so genius here believes I am one of them. I was so pissed off that I no longer wanted to work for this crummy shithead or his company. Needless to say I told him he was a stupid bastard and hoped he he got into an accident forcing him to become handicapped then yanked my resume out of his hands and stormed out of his office. 

I was there to get hired as a 3rd party telephone collector which I had five years previous experience and a letter of recommendation with me. This was one of the top five most humiliating experiences of my life to be certain. If anyone ever deserved a brain aneurysm, THAT idiot did.

That was when two friends and I decided to open our own collection agency. One was a woman and the other was a guy who too many employers said was "too old" so the three of us started one, got it up and running and two years later we sold it to a different rival agency. So sometimes a bad learning experience can turn something disgusting into something terrific.
comments.author: @molochsorcery4357

comments.text: I am not sure if I agree with all of this. IF you read these statements, I would say that you should not put any weight in that. Your job is to land an interview with a real person that is close to where you are going to work like workers, team leads, closest boss. If you are on first interview and you only meet HR or some remote being, then again do not put much into this gibberish. Most companies must make some statements, and these are made late at night by people that just want to get over with it. I will go as far as saying that, unless you have inside information, then you cannot tell if the place is going to be good or bad. You take the job, and you should prepare yourself to quit early if expectations is not met. I would focus on asking the right questions in interview and do phone calls to figure out if the job is not for you. But in the end you can only do so much. Too many questions and asked in wrong way will make you unhirable. So you can only do so much.

comments.text:
Great advice. Applies equally in the UK jobs market. I wish I'd had it 40 years ago (now in my 60s).

* I have worked for a company starting up (the 5th employee, counting the two founders) who "work hard, play hard" and ended up working 100 hour weeks and going on "team bonding days" which started on Friday and ended on a weekend at the other end of the country. Leaving them was particularly challenging as finding time for interviews with prospective employers could only be accomplished by "throwing a sickie".
* I made the mistake of returning to a company who laid me off. The engineering team I worked with were brilliant but within ten months the management had laid me off a second time. I would not relieve myself in their pockets if their gonads were on fire.
* Finally a company I have worked for three different times. The work was great, the management good on a day-to-day basis. Why leave? We had to support our products globally and were expected to travel in our own time. Worst case was from the UK to Mexico. From shutting my front door on the way out to shutting my hotel door in Mexico on arrival took 25 hours. All unpaid.

comments.text: I also think that some organizations can be 'family'-like without it being a negative.  A better word might be community.  I worked for a university, that in its earlier days, was very family oriented and that carried over to how bosses treated employees, but in a good way.  it was common in this place for people to actually care about others, and the university did nice things for their employees - like a big family picnic every summer at a park with games and ice cream trucks for the kids.  Employees loved this stuff.  They also liked their bosses who actually asked them how their families were doing, and career wise - gave them opportunities to grow.  My own father was a facilities director who was highly regarded by his employees because of how well he treated them ( I heard first-hand many stories like this).  My (ex) father in law was hired by him, with this story:  Father in law, at a much younger age and with a young family, was on strike at job.  He wouldn't cross the picket line, but he needed to work.  He came to this university looking for work, and my father said:  Are you willing to do (this kind of) work?  He hired my future father in law on the spot (you could do that in those days), and my FIL ended up staying there until the day he retired.  As he told the story, my dad gave him a job so he could feed his kids, when other companies would not, because of the strike.  It's a different world today, and I think we have lost some of this humanity in the workplace.  People used to actually want that because work was part of one's identity, and for many people it was rewarding and fulfilling.  Most bosses today flat out suck.
comments.author: @theresaferero3757

comments.text: The first two "We work hard and play hard" and "We treat each other like family" are red flags that you will be exploited. You will be expected to work long hours, outside of work hours without being paid any more for it (except for some 'social' activity that you don't want to join in but are forced to on pain of not being a 'team player') - because 'family' do things for each other for free. If companies start talking they are like family, what they are really saying is that they expect you to commit your time and effort to the company at the expense of your actual family. They are also lying to your face, so it's a sign of things to come. This could also mean that 'they' (the ones who run the company) treat each other like family, because they are actual family, meaning nepotism and favouritism will be rampant and everyone else (i.e. you) will not be given the same opportunities or respect (or any respect). Definitely keep away from these companies.
comments.author: @realantithesis6137

comments.text:
I worked for 11 months for a major etailer, and helped to set up one of its fulfillment centers. managers were expected to get rid of 10% of their employees every year, regardless of overall performance levels. This was likely a factor in workplace violence that was getting people fired. Many of us suspected a high proportion of substance abuse, as it was hard to maintain performance. 
Although I expected a low level of average seniority at a new site, what was troubling was that even the core cadre starting up this new facility had less than three years with the company. Found one guy who must have been with them since the company's founding, and told him I thought this was "the world's biggest disorganization." He laughed in agreement.
On an assignment to verify capital inventory, I found physically large items they had no record of. Another time, I was sent to find a rental lift truck (how do you lose something like that?). Product inventory was likewise bad; they had three or four employees whose sole task was to randomly look for items to verify they could be found; inventory shortages were astounding.
Needless to say, I wouldn't buy stock in this company.
comments.author: @et76039

comments.text:
I’ll add a few more.

1. “Don’t talk about your salary”.
Employees are on the same side. Get your raises and your worth.

2. “We both hurt if this company doesn’t do well”. 
Kind of true, but it implies we have equal stakes in it. You’re the ceo, I’m not.

3. Similarly, “I work hard late/weekends so everyone should be doing it too!”
Again, you’re the CEO. I’m not getting paid what you’re getting paid.

Lastly, work for a place that celebrates or at least gives good wishes to an employee who leaves for a better job. Not a place that suggests they abandoned the team for more money or simply ignores them and pretends they never existed.

comments.text:
I think the "foosball table" thing is more important that one might think. I used to work at a place with bad working environment and a very difficult CEO to work with. He would be very charismatic and charm people when they did the interview, and one thing he would always say is "we have happy hours on Friday!", "we have lunch together", "X guy is going next week for some vacations, but there's plenty of work to do!". In other words, what he was saying is "hey, totally DO NOT WORRY that you won't have long working hours -- and here is the evidence so DO TRUST me!".

If a workplace values employee's times, they won't try to charm you with "cool stuff" that they do at the office. They will want to know about your experience, and they will be quite transparent about working hours. No smoke and mirrors, just plain answers and sensible policy.

Also I would add "unlimited PTO". Nine out of ten chances you'll have less PTO than with a regular policy.

comments.text:
You don't really get the "We're a Family" treatment unless your boss is in the grind with you like a blue collar job. Worked for a family owned Landscaping business and my Boss was with us everyday installing sprinklers, putting down sawd and building planter boxes. He talked to me like I was his own son and encouraged me to go to medical school. He had a BS in Botany because he loved plants, loved knowing the science behind what makes plants grow and he loved owning his own business. 

That said, the moment I started working white collar jobs while going to school the "family image" of the work place died. I've been denied raises and been fired for trivial things. Now that I'm on my way to an MD I've learned two things.

1. Work for yourself. Don't let your hard earned skills be at the mercy of people who would pay you 1/10 of the profit you bring in if you let them.
2. Be the boss you wish you had. Life is more than just the bottom line, treat your help like people and they'll show loyalty to your goals.

comments.text: While I agree with most of the sentiments here, one of the biggest problems, especially with large organizations and the government, is that too much in BENEFITS is tied to length-of-service. It's a huge act of trust these days for a new employee to invest 10 or 15 irreplaceable years, but once they reach a certain point the whole sunken-cost mindset takes over and they become risk-averse pushovers just trying to make it to retirement. Even though they're burnt out to a crisp and are constaly getting work piled on by deliberate understaffing. It won't be a truly level playing field until we can make key benefits completely PORTABLE. Like mandated minimum vacation time. Or health care, pensions or 401ks. Those can all be used and have been used to velvet-handcuff people.

comments.text: Someee of this is good advice, but it also kind of only applies to mid-high end managerial jobs, or tech/office jobs. That’s just capitalism, and labor jobs. Deal with it while you work your way up, and show yourself to not be expendable. The landscaping company where I work, I see so many guys come in with no experience, expect the same wages and people who have been there for years, and then sit on their butts and do nothing. But then they try to make the argument about how they “know their worth” etc. it’s kind of become a joke, and it’s in large part due to a massive influx of media telling people they’re worth more than they really are.
comments.author: @burlehmangus

comments.text:
"We expect you to go above and beyond the call of duty." First of all, unless we're talking about video games, there's no such thing as "Call of Duty." Soldiers fighting in a war are not following some romantic passion, they've been press-ganged into service by a government. There's no call of duty at work either. You exchange your labour for currency so you can keep and support the things you actually do care about. All of this is the subject of a business contract. Everything you do in a day should be part of that contract.

You might need to add a few tasks to your job once in a while, because they need to get done in order for you to keep operating normally, but if its clear the company just expects you to do those tasks regularly, or are relying on you to do it to avoid having to hire someone to fill that role, you add it to your job contract and you get compensated for it. When you hire a plumber to unblock your pressure vent, do they fix your leaky faucet for free just because the notice it? Of course not, and you shouldn't do stuff like that either.

And then there's the nebulousness of the term. What does it mean to go "above and beyond?" How much more do you have to do? How many extra hours? What are the most valuable ways to go above and beyond? How am I being rewarded for any of this? The company says they EXPECT you to go above and beyond, sometimes they even write those words on job postings, so does that mean going "above and beyond" is actually doing "the bare minimum?" Ask your manager, you'll find out he thinks so.

When you're in an abusive relationship weather it's with a person or a corporation, one way the abuser keeps control is to obfuscate all the boundaries, expectations, and goals. They don't want you knowing what you're doing! They want everything to be chaotic and uncertain so you're always responding, always fixing things, always compensating, and the only reward you expect for that is a few minutes free of their complaints and tantrums, and you never really get it. Working for a legitimate business shouldn't be like that.
comments.author: @ZogDaMegnivizint

comments.text:
I can't agree with your recommendation that you stay away from a company that says "You are replaceable".  They're being truthful.  I'd rather work for a company that was upfront and honest about the reality of the situation than one which will bullsh*t to my face and tell me that I'm a special snowflake.  Nobody is irreplaceable.  Learning that lesson is painful but necessary for personal career growth.  The agreement between employer and employee isn't personal.  As the employee, you are selling your labor "commodity" to the company.  That arrangement can be terminated at any point for any reason by either side.  You aren't valued by your employer for just being there - you're valued based on how you contribute to the shareholders' portfolios.
My personal warning sign is "we encourage our team members to bring their whole-selves to work."  That sophist bullsh*t really gets under my skin.  Under no circumstances should you bring your "whole self" to work.  You leave your personal life at the door.  You don't need to burden your coworkers with your nonsense drama and neuroses.

comments.text: I got the "Work hard, play hard" line from a manager at a major network device company in the 90s who had a major campus off 75/Central in Richardson. Was just starting my career and was thinking "What the hell is that supposed to mean?" while smiling and saying "Oh, that's great." Glad I did not get the job since it was a true cattle call interview. They had 100+ people show up and set the interviews in the cafeteria area. There were three rounds of interviews divided between three tables: something like Tier 1 and Tier 2 technical then manager. They also had two sets of these tracks to interview multiple candidates at once. Worse, everything was public to be seen by all other candidates and noisy as hell. So, every other candidate got to see your walk of shame if you did not get the job. I passed all technical questions but did not get the green light with the manager. In hindsight, that was a good thing since they got hit hard with layoffs later but the cattle call style interview system left a memorable impression. 10 years ago, that massive campus was divided up and sold off after the company who owned it went bankrupt.

comments.text:
If there is an (unspoken) mismatch between

1)  what an employee thinks their value is in the career/jobs marketplace
2)  and what the company thinks the employee's value is

It's like a marriage between a highly-paid runway model and a painter.   

It might work briefly in the beginning, but at some point, one party will say  "I make $1 million per year wearing skimpy outfits on fashion 'runways' around the world, and you post ads on craigslist trying to get your next painting job."

The breakup scene between Bill Murray - a taxi driver - and his hot girlfriend at the start of the movie "Stripes" comes to mind.

Even if your initial value to the employer is perceived to be high initially, it can fade over time and you might not realize it, and even if you do, it might be caused by a change in the company's business conditions or a change in the market (Facebook giving up on the 'metaverse' is one example).

If you're operating a business and hiring people,  it's quite a shock, how much your thinking about the employee experience shifts.  The whims of the marketplace that dictate your competitiveness is just not  "top-of-mind" with employees.  

To say this another way,  the certainty/stability you feel as an employee  ("I'm still employed, that means I'm getting my paycheck, no problem")  changes when you run the business  ("we have to meet payroll and 2/3rds of our sales team is underperforming").

While it's been enjoyable in a way to experience both roles  (employee and owner),  it's pretty astonishing, the beliefs that the employee has about the business, and the beliefs the business has about the employees.   They can differ, vastly.
.
comments.author: @Greg_Chase

comments.text: All we’re missing IS a fooseball table! If I’d known the company I work for was going to be like this, I would have ran after the first day. It was a small company when I first started and it didn’t seem that bad. I had been a hairdresser for many years and got burnt out. I was looking for steady pay and benefits, so it wasn’t bad. I decided to stay. Then after a year and waiting to get hired (that was the the way they did things back then, waited a year to hire anyone, I guess to make sure you were serious about the job). I really wasn’t aware of how warehouse jobs operated. It all seemed ok at the time as it seemed things were operating pretty fairly. Once we were bought out by a bigger company, they enticed us by saying our pay would increase by a few dollars. What we didn’t realize, or should I say, what I didn’t realize is how “woke” and how more toxic it would become. If you don’t “play ball” in their way, you will be picked apart and depending on where you are from or if you are one of the original members from the previous company, they tried to get rid of all of the original staff. They did a good job of it too by firing anyone who stepped out of line at all. They almost had me but I made sure to keep my mouth shut and not admit or react to any of their false accusations. If I didn’t need a job so bad and things that are going on in the world where they are laying off so many. I’d leave! My job is an essential worker job, so that’s the only reason I stay. It does suck and I see everything going on. I know anywhere I’m gonna go, it’s going to be this way. This is the new normal. Hopefully, when a new administration comes into power, I’ll have a better chance at getting a different job that’s secure as well as where I’m currently at. Till then, I go in do what I’m asked/told. Then go home! I no longer strive to try and go above and beyond coz it doesn’t matter to them. I’m not apart of the clicks and that’s fine. They’ll get theirs. What goes around comes around. Maybe not at work, but they’ll see when their kids grow up and those same things happen to their kids. Either way, they are not going to run me off. I’m stronger than that. I’m also smarter than I let them think. It may seem like it doesn’t make sense but I’m paying attention and talking notes.

comments.text: THANK YOU FOR SAYING!!!!  I've run into every one of these over a 35 year career in accounting / finance.  That "fast-paced environment" one especially.  In the end, KEEP YOUR EYES / EARS OPEN and IT IS ALL ABOUT "FIT".  Work where your time will reap the greatest return in whatever you value.  Some of those "toxic workplaces" are where the greatest opportunity came.  We're all self-employed...you either sell your services to one employer or several customers.    The employer/customer pays you to provide a value greater than your cost.  The employer/customer wants to reduce that cost & need...while you are striving to increase your cost & tenure.  So your whole career will dance around that conflict.  Don't take it personally.   It's not sad....it's just reality.

comments.text: Coming back here after seven months, I want to point out how many business owners have rushed to their own defense in the comments section below. Exactly zero. America is in free-fall and most of the population has shut down. People are sufficiently miserable just being alive without having to worry about whether or not their bosses are assholes. It boils down to professionalism, in the fullest sense of the word. By that measure, 98% of American businesses simply fail. Professionalism gives the employee the edge. Failing to have a written, detailed policy handbook goes hand in hand with operating a crappy business, as do double standards and cronyism. Yet they're rampant throughout the United States. This is the nature of the world of work and there's not much--if anything--an employee can do to change it.

comments.text:
Here's one that happened to me when I was interviewing for my first job.  I answered the salary question with the number that was the going rate in the region for a starting salary in my profession.  The interviewer actually flinched.  It was an unconscious movement and I do not think that he was ever aware of it.  This was on a Friday.  I was then asked to come back on Monday for a follow-up interview.  When another prospective employer called me on the weekend and made me an offer that was even better than  the price I named, the flinch sealed the deal.

Now here is the funny part.  I called first thing Monday and cancelled the follow-up.  I told the guy that I had been offered and accepted a position over the weekend.  I also said that it was for more than I had asked for.  He then started complaining about how unfair it was for someone to call me on the weekend like that.  THEN he asked me how much I was offered.  I told him.  His response was "Oh we could never have payed that."  The flinch had been real.
comments.author: @mikepennington8088

At the time, because so many companies went belly up, and it was very difficult to find work, because of the shut downs, I accepted the position and collected unemployment as well. With that said they explained that they couldn’t hire me back full-time and then I was rehired full-time the following year when I did question their intentions. Hearing what you said really makes me regret accepting their offer. However, every experience has its benefit I did build some skills and this video really has inspired me to Re-update my résumé and acknowledge the skills I do currently have in addition to what I’ve learned from my current position. That’s my story.
