He was told he couldn't have one but he was eligible to take a one week paid vacation but he would have to take it before the end of the year. So he decide to take the vacation in December before the end of the year. He was then told he couldn't take it because we are short handed. He then asked to take in in January but was told he could take it but he would have to work on Friday and Saturday. I'm not making this up either.

comments.text: Oh, don't I know it. My boss was upset I had signed up for a one-person shift. I'll admit I'm kind of a slow learner and do much better with a helping hand and guide, but come on, that's no excuse for being insensitive. One of our student leader's responsibilities is organizing who works which shifts on the schedule, and my boss scolded him for not noticing I had signed up for a one-person shift. When she asked him if she thought I could do the shift, I answered for him with a firm "yes," because I felt belittled by her. She said she didn't think so, was all "I've told you not to sign up for shifts by yourself, I've been very clear about that, I don't know how much clearer I can get for you to listen" (something like that, so I'm not perfectly quoting her), and she told me I need someone there to give me instructions and guide me. I regretfully didn't stand up for myself, because I was intimidated. Well, now I harbor a huge amount of resentment toward her, and I pretty much don't care about her anymore. Of course, I can't quit just because of her, because the job itself is actually beneficial. I just wish she didn't work there anymore.

comments.text: My take after 30 years in business.  Words mean nothing.  Actions are everything.  Some companies are great.  Some are bad.  Some employees are great.  Some are bad.  Bottom line, it’s a two way street between employee and employer.  It’s up to you as an employee to ensure you are getting a fair deal here and now. It’s a business relationship.  The company is looking out for their interests.  You must look after yours.  That’s the way it’s supposed to be.  It’s not a good business deal if one side is taking advantage of the other.

comments.text:
Nail on the head.

You want the job to earn your money. The company wants you to do the job to earn THEM money. It's a simple as that. The owner cares about the business growing and being profitable, because it's his investment, if it fails it's his money and his life getting fucked, if it becomes worth millions it's his millions. You care about your paycheck at the end of the month, if the company's bottom line is looking good or bad is not your job to worry about (unless you get paid in shares in which case things change drastically since it's also partly yours, but hardly anyone ever does that any more unless you're a top director).

And nothing said to you that isn't written down is ultimately worth fuck all, don't stick around if you can make better money elsewhere RIGHT NOW, you can't pay any bills with empty promises. If the market changes in such a way that keeping you around is not profitable for them any more you can bet your ass they'll fire you too.
comments.author: @BigUriel

comments.text:
I am not arguing with you here, but I feel the need to elaborate for other's sake. 

A good company understands all this and then goes beyond that to also make sure the employee understands. The employee should not be the one bringing this concept to the table. One employee is not going to change the course of a business, so if that is you don't kid yourself. That atmosphere needs to exist prior to an employee arriving. 

That said, that same company will also understand people are people and work to make the workplace a good atmosphere with some cooperation and compassion and no drama and selfishness(related to work). Drama kills efficiency and productivity. Drama takes good workers and gives them a reason to leave. 
Me first attitudes create drama. 
And I do not mean people taking care of their own lives. I mean people prioritizing their own advancement and personal workload over their job requirements and efficiency of their coworkers. The good company already has a workload expectation that is reasonable and communicated. The me first person will try to skirt that. You know the type, they show up as the "yes man" and are very good talkers but do not walk the talk, and do not work as a team with their group. They expect cooperation and offer none. That mentality conflicts with any notion of a pleasant place to work. So people need to be careful about meanings when they say "take care of yourself first". It can be taken too far.
comments.author: @davenhla

comments.text:
I’m currently working for a company that has used the word we are family. During the pandemic in 2020 myself and many others were laid off. When I reached out to the one owner about being reinstated, my email was ignored. I was then hired back as a different role and stripped of my benefits. 

When I questioned my one supervisor about the owner’s intentions on hiring me back for full-time, I was told that they don’t have the funds to hire me back. In that conversation I did indicate that I need to know because my role that I was forced into was seasonal and the season was over I need to start looking for new employment. I met for lunch with my one supervisor and I was then hired back full time in my original role. 

Sadly I don’t feel of value and I’m still being treated the same way. After much consideration, I have revised my resume and have been reevaluating my career with the hopes to find something more fulfilling and more prosperous. 

Your video is very helpful and there’s so much more I want to say.

comments.text:
I started in my new company just 7 months ago. I already sensed the red flags but I was desperate for job. First, the hr who handled my recruitment was hard to communicate with. I got my job offer letter and there were no info on the benefits that I would get so I asked since I also had another job offer. The HR was not responding to my chats even if I know they were active. In the end, I still chose their offer since it was the exact position (Design Manager) that I wanted and the company is a well known brand in our country.

Little did I know, when I finally came in for work, the team that I was suppose to join was not even aware that I was hired. Then, it turned out that the president wanted me to be a QS/ Cost Analysis Manager and also lead the team.

I was shocked. I clearly told them that I don't have any experiences or skills in quantity surveying since I am an architect for most of my career. My CV is clear about that. But I didn't have a choice. I tried to do my best, even got regularized in just 4 months but I still hate my job. I even hate the fact that we do nkt have a clear process or workflow in the company, favoritism is rampant, hardworking employees are just given more work and even handling contractors and suppliers is stressful because they have personal relationships or connections with the owners.

Now I am just trying to take it day by day and actively looking for a new role that fits my skills and experiences. I would also like to just be able to work for myself in the near future.

comments.text:
Another red flag is “good learning opportunity” in the context of low-paid jobs and/or trainee positions. In some cases, they indeed give you access to a professional field as a trainee at the cost of a low salary, and you can gain useful marketable knowledge for your future carrier. 

However, you’ve gotta pay special attention to these “good learning opportunity” company lines while you are still a rookie because it might also happen that they would pass over - only and exclusively - the paperwork to you, which no one wants to do, and then you gain nothing but a shitty job for cents. In these cases, the only reason why they wrap such a position into a “trainee” covering is that they ain’t got a budget, indeed no experience is needed for the job, and it must be done... So then, there you go sonny boy, you’re on the hook.

By all this, I don’t mean that as a trainee you should thematically refuse the paperwork or low-level tasks because it might be the case that an employer tests you and for example, paperwork is also a part of the job for seniors too. However, let’s say they still treat you poorly at the end of your probationary period, then it might be possibly the time to quit as fast as you can because they only wasting your time and potential.

comments.text:
Your employees are miserable and you are too clueless to realize how draconian your policies are. You are treating the job as though it is more important than anything else in the lives of your employees. 

You had a handful of employees who abused perks and privileges and your bright solution was to become a tyrannical, toxic despot of a boss who is more focused on catching the 2% who end up abusing perks and privileges instead of rewarding and focusing on the 98% who are truly honorable. 

Yup...that makes sense. That makes about as much sense as a screen door on a submarine. 

You do not carry all the risk. While you may be an employer, it is your employees, the human capital, that keeps your doors open. Your employees are the most important and most valuable resource you have; take care of them and they will go the extra mile for you. 

You may know how to be in charge, but you don't know how to lead, to be a leader. There's more to being a boss than being in charge and telling people what to do.

comments.text:
That should have been my red flag, but I truly loved the work so I endured stuff that you wouldn’t believe. I mean seriously the requirements were crazy by UK standards. I mean I stayed there long enough to get the full security clearance that only about 20% of the new starters stay around long enough to get. I was literally in the middle of a training course that would have made me infinitely more useful to them and was late because I needed to get my prescription medication that I need daily. I warned them about this and yet I still scraped in just in time for the course. But one of the managers seriously hated me and it was mutual and that day one of the higher ranking managers just happened to be in and he didn’t like my explanation.

A couple hours later I’m just finishing my lunch break when I got called into the office to be told I was being fired on the spot for my poor attendance rate which was slightly below normal due to factors that aren’t the employee’s fault. Yes, I’d withstood the time and abuse, I’d shown dedication beyond that would have been expected to me but because I pissed off the manager they fired me on impulse.

Fortunately by this point a part of me seemed to sense that I was being abused and the mutual hatred between me and the manager was a huge problem despite my being professional if cold with her because I’d basically negotiated with another company that do the same thing but were happy to take me on. I was in the midst of deciding if I wanted to go through the whole trouble of paperwork and security clearance switching between companies but the situation was decided for me. I’m better off now, even if they work me a bit harder.

comments.text:
My experience with a "We are like a Family" styled company was this:

My grandfather had an alergic reaction to a new med. it exacerbated his COPD and his brain died from lack of oxygen. They narrowly kept his body alive. I put in a SINGLE day off, which i literally never ever do, to go come to terms with his death as they pulled the plug. That day work called wanting me to come in anyway. They needed me in 10 minutes despite the fact i was physically 4+ hours away and when i explained i wasn't coming bc family, distance, my mental state at the moment they said "What about us? We're also like your family?".

Needless to say i hung up and fired up my resume. I got written up for 'missing' work when i got back. I didn't stay much longer and when i was a shift leader at another company i came back and poached all the good employees. Now they are basically ruined.

comments.text:
So I was hired by a company as a Supervisor. I arrived at the first job site and unloaded some of my tools.
The supervisor above me screamed at me to get the tools off the job site. First time I have ever been screamed at for having tools. I am required to have my own hand tools for the job. Second day I asked my supervisor how the workers were supposed to tie off in their harnesses to stay safe and the supervisor screamed at me again saying they know what they are doing. That evening I went and bought a bodycam to record these interactions. Third day I asked my immediate supervisor same person if there was a certain spot that they have to set up their laser for centering . Instead of yes or no. She screamed at me again that they know what they are doing. A week and a half into the job . The guys working under me would not tie off, wear safety glasses or stay of their phones. I would ask them to tie off or wear their safety glasses or something to that effect and they would ignore me or tell me to duck off. I was hired as a Supervisor yet I was doing hard labor work the whole time I was there. The machine we were building, per the specifications was not allowed to use a steel hammer on any of it unless to drive an anchor into the floor. The workers under me would constantly use a steel hammer on the feet of it and I would repeatedly tell them that the manufacturer doesn't want that done. I reported it to my supervisor. Tuesday I told one of the workers to not use the steel hammer anymore. He tried to hit me in the head with it. I caught it as he swung it at me. He swung his other fist at me and I caught it also. I told him you have to calm down and leave. My supervisor said that they are my workers and you need to leave. I have all of my time on video and Audio as that after the second day I knew that I was in a hostile and toxic work environment. That guy is still on the job. I'm not. He tried to hit me with a 4 pound hammer! What should I do?

comments.text: I'd actually disagree. While that may mean that they have people continously applying sometimes, that is typically followed by high turnover, hence the constant hiring. The high turnover should be an indicator of what to expect.

comments.text: @bobmoneybags6075  maybe I should rephrase my first sentence: "We're always hiring" CAN be an indication of a strong organization. It's not given that this phrase means a company has a high turnover rate. First of all, there's natural attrition (ie retirements, leaves of absence, etc). A company must stay ahead of those. Secondly, the differentiator is volume; I can always be on the lookout for highly talented people and find a way to employ them in ways that are mutually beneficial. But if I'm bringing in, say, 5%+ of my company's head count per month over a prolonged period, then that may be an indication of high turnover.
comments.author: @curtiscox6469

comments.text: A Life After Layoff: As I've mentioned in other videos of yours, it seems to me that the primary vector differentiating a good company from a bad company is cold hard cash.  If you're hired at a place which pays well, provides first class health benefits and easily accessible vacation or PTO, you'll definitely  be much happier than at a place that struggles to balance its books or relies on annual state or federal monies to pay its employees. During a job interview, ask the recruiter if the company has a budget sufficient to supply all the materials you'll need to actually do your job. If you receive an answer such as, "We recycle paper clips" or "sometimes we just don't have the resources"--run like hell. Note the condition of your surroundings. Is there a wastebasket overflowing in the interview/conference room? Is the break room/kitchen in good shape? How about the rest rooms? I'm not saying don't take a job at a non-profit or 501C-3. Those businesses often pay well and take good care of their employees. But you'll find absolutely appalling conditions in the offices of most Big Ten universities--both physical and psychological--and in many start-ups. Don't even get me started on county offices, some of which in Minnesota are still using DOS. A final word to the wise, if the company is indeed "like family," that sometimes means a single approved top-down mindset. The family patriarch/business owner will make your life miserable if you demonstrate any trace of independent thought or initiative--and that goes for everything from company policies to the art on the walls. (I was once hired as office manager at the satellite office of a southern law firm. The satellite was in St. Paul, MN--very hip and together--while corporate was in Dallas. As an office-warming gift, we received from corporate a huge sculpture of a First Nations man riding a horse, which would be beautiful were it not for the title of the piece, namely "Horse Thief." This occurred in 2004. In Minnesota, a major First Nations community. We also received five-pointed yellow stars as "stressbusters" from the same corporate office.) Unfortunately, I've discovered that good, solvent, healthy, employee-friendly companies are a tiny minority in the United States. It's no surprise that the Covid-19 pandemic has brought the worst ones to their knees.
comments.author: @maxalberts2003

comments.text:

comments.text: Most of the places I've worked at had some of those signs, but at very low intensity - I guess I lucked out, or maybe I ran away from the toxic ones. For example, I worked using "multiple hats", but only because it really was a startup company. I think they were running for less than 2 years when I entered. I had no issues there - Despite making some errors, I had the opportunity to learn many lessons, even bitter ones. I also worked at a "cool workplace" company for about a year, the client was utterly terrible leading the project, but the coworkers were great, and since the client never had the guts to launch the project, I felt like working in a "sandbox company" for quite some time, giving me opportunities to experiment a lot. My current place also has some issues - Some of them related to turnover, some related to the client, but I also had the opportunity to learn how to work for a long time running project, and for a very public and big client.

It's an extension to what I usually do, but the extra work is actually supposed to be done by another department, and I still get paid the same for doing it. The drivers in the other department do less than I do. comments.text:
I kind of disagree with the "we wear multiple hats" objection. Every job I've ever worked I've had to wear many hats in order to be good at it. I've worked for huge companies and I'm currently working for a tiny company.
What does wearing many hats mean? It means that you're expected to be good at many things, most of which aren't that difficult to do if your well organized, resourceful and time efficient.
The important thing is that if you are working for a small company, wearing many hats, make sure you document all of the extra responsibilities that you had on your resume, and prepare to speak about it in an interview. If you're interviewing with a large company, relate to them how those skills are scalable to a larger company, and you'll sound more like someone who is capable of management and less like an entry level employee who just gets work dumped on them.

comments.text:
Sooo…… exactly how did they GET so negative?  LOL. I’m 64 and it took me too long to realize this all important fact. 

When in an interview I’m not there to grovel for a job. I’m there to interview THEM to see if the reward will be equal to the sacrifices required. I’m also ascertaining if I will like who is already there. If no on any question I thank them and end the process. 

I was on two different interviews where they acted annoyed that I was asking THEM questions. One was what I could see was a revolving door company. The recruiter when realizing I might be too perceptive just shoved an application across the table. 

I guess she could tell by my less than enthusiastic demeanor I was losing interest at an alarming rate. 

I told her I hadn’t decided yet if I even WANTED the job yet and watched the angry micro expression in her eyes. She quickly recovered and resumed the used car salesman smile but the gig was up. 

I really enjoyed sliding the application back her way!  

As others here have said. You work for YOU LLC.

comments.text: Holy $hit! I spent 35 years working at one of these "We treat our workers like family" type places. They treated me and many others like $hit. Is that how you treat your family? When I started we had a 1/2 half hour unpaid lunch break and 2 15 minute paid breaks. The 1/2 hour break got taken away a few years after I started.  The 15 minute breaks took over and the production lines kept running. ( I was a food factory worker) The line operator had to take the workers place as they went on break and returned one by one. The owner of my current employer has said, "we don't have job descriptions around here". I'm pretty sure in his mind that means "everybody does what it takes to get things done". That's fine to a point, but when people are trying to do things they aren't trained for it can get pretty ugly. Its also not very cost effective for me to unload trucks at my pay scale (middle management), but sometimes I do it just for a break and to get the point across that maybe they should have job descriptions.

I do wear a lot of hats, but I'm paid hourly so I just focus on the priorities and catch up the rest when I have time. Worst case I let it slide until it doesn't matter any more.

I've worked at a lot worse places.

comments.text:
First job out of college: "You'll only be a contractor for 3 months and then be hired in for almost double the pay and actual benefits."

Manager at 6-month performance review: "You've exceeded all performance marks, engaged in professional development, completed multiple extra certifications, you take on overtime when it's needed, and everyone on the floor says you're great to work with!" 

Me: "Does that mean I'll be fully hired in so I can get benefits and an 80% pay bump, like the recruiter said would happen 3 months ago?"


Manager: "I can't control what recruiters say. Spots are filled based on seniority. We don't expect another hiring round for at least 6 months, and there are four employees ahead of you in line." 

Me: *Quietly decides to do the absolute least amount of work possible and take as many breaks as I can on the clock as possible without getting fired. Checks email all day, takes multiple, extended lunch breaks with different groups of people, etc. 

Manager at 9-month performance review: "You're performance is still excellent, and we think you're ready for more responsibilities. We still can't promise you a pay raise and benefits for at least 9 more months, but two people in front of you in line have left, so you'll probably get in at the next hiring round."

Me: "I'm quitting. I'll give you six weeks notice, but if I find something else soon enough, I'll revise that down."

My former "boss" actually told us one day that he "loved us like his own family".

     I'd say "no, I'm just here for a paycheck", with the most disgusted look on my face that I could pull off. It only took a matter of months of him pulling his little backwards manipulations to get me to quit. It worked. I quit the company I'd been with for 15 years.

I don’t think he knows that it wouldn’t be the first time I managed people so he thinks it’s more alluring than it actually is. So the day they changed my job duties they let me know that for a short time I would be doing what was supposed to be two people’s jobs but I was definitely going to shed some of the other things that I was doing so I could focus. THEN he called me back when his leader wasn’t on the line to ask me to do part of a third person’s job, but to do it in secret so she would get credit. He didn’t want her to get overwhelmed. Then he asked me to design the processes and reporting for a whole new department while I was doing two people’s work and secretly doing part of a third person’s job. The company is a family and they only hire rock stars. They are always hiring. They work hard and play hard. All that stuff.

comments.text: I needed this. I just got fired from a bad employer. I'm a manager with 15 years of experience, and I was just hired 2 months ago by a franchise to help build their business and bring in sales. Somehow, in 2 months, they expected me to bring up sales from 50k a month to 85k without knowing the full insurance and outs aswell as running a position that took me away from my managerial duties. I missed one day of work, so I only worked 30 hours one week and made it up on a day off on the next week and accumulated 9 hours of overtime... when they brought me in the office and told me they had to move money out of one account into another to cover my over time that I apparently racked up just got me. Being in two months, I had a total of 16 hours of OT, and they could not afford it? Everything you said in this video was them, but I still accepted the job because I wanted something new. While checking employees' old-time punches, I discovered days of time missing that they worked and were not paid. I brought it up to the DM, and she told me not to tell them. red flags after red flags. Last week, I had a feeling they were going to fire me and had already started looking for a new job. I cannot believe people like this can run a business and I told them while exiting that if they continue with those expectations of managers to know everything in 2 months while not providing adequate training aswell as not providing employees with pto, paid holidays, suck days and complete summers being blocked different from taking time off then they are doomed to fail. I wish I knew what I could do. I want to contact the main corporate of the franchise butt cannot seem to find contact info. Thank you for this video, and good luck to everyone who was able to overcome the toxicity or remember their value enough to leave. Some people do not deserve what they have, and others who do get the shit end of the stick it seems . Good luck to everyone! ❤

comments.text:
My company uses this concept and the word team frequently. But it is used to mean support your coworkers, don't use drama to bring them down. it is used to mean if you have a rough time, there is some compassion for people being people with people problems, and that the company will work with you so you don't have to worry about your job while you deal with things. 
It isn't used to mean any of the weird creepy stuff this guy talks about. it is about teamwork, cooperation, and understanding. 

The job market is very tough, on both ends of things nowdays, especially for niche industries. Your company and boss should not be your friend and family, you shouldn't prioritize them as such, and you need to be yourself and remain an individual. But your company should understand you are "people" and people have problems in life. your coworkers don;t need to be your friend, but they need to understand they are your coworker whether they like it or not and offer cooperation and support, not drama and dismissal. 

Maybe because my company is in rural midwest that these concepts are not distorted? Look at society in our country as a whole, the idea of family and group cooperation vs. the individual and selfishness is slanted very heavily to broken homes with single parents and an emphasis on "me first" so if you live somewhere else the words probably have a different meaning or weight. 
I think it comes down to intention and atmosphere, not the particular terms used.
comments.author: @davenhla

comments.text: @ghost_mall  it is the intentions behind the terms, not the words themselves that matter. Our country has become so slanted to broken homes with single parents and a focus on the individual and "me first" that words like family do not mean the same as they used to. you have to evaluate the atmosphere and intent, not just listen to the words.

comments.text:
Hello, Brian. I know this question may sound weird and if you see this, may you do me a favour of answering me if one of my friend's manager is a toxic or just an incompetent boss? My friend told me about the following that is observed from the manager:

1) When my friend got hired and accepted, the manager says to my friend "Welcome to the family"
2) The manager sets many unrealistic expectations emphasizing on competition without considering what the outside market is currently facing
3) The manager favours people who do a better job and gives more clients to these people (In the industry that my friend works in, the more clients you have, the more money you will make)
4) When my friend tries to work hard and informs the manager about work status, the manager says a lot of negatives toward my friend
5) My friend tried to have a regular conversation with the manager and my friend finds that the manager is not speaking English properly despite during the interview, my friend says to me the manager seemed nice, approachable, and even  had a wonderful casual conversation
6) My friend was heavily placed in a huge disadvantaged situation by the manager after making a mistake or making a brutal honest opinion
7) When my friend asks for help, the manager will say that the manager is very busy
8) When my friend shares reflections with the manager after a serious incident has happened, my friend tells me that the manager says things like "I am not new to the industry". Is this a sign of arrogance?
9) My friend suspects that the manager does take part credit every time there is a client who gives positive feedback and who wants to continue to make business with the industry my friend is currently working in 
10) My manager once told my friend "some people love our institute because they care"

Sorry for keep using the words "friend" and "manager".  I want to protect the identities of my friend and the manager, that's why

comments.text:
I am in a situation where I do have a job line up and it starts mid next month and where I work the notice period is 1 week. Sounds a lot easier to quit the job right, well not exactly the company salary payment cycle is 1 month and they paid mid of the month about 14th each month, for 2 weeks in arrears and 2 weeks in advance, when I quit I give 1 week notice period a day after I get paid (from a moral value point of view I feel guilty as I felt like too calculative quit the day I get my monthly paid).

However, I will write in my resignation letter that I will work until the end of the month since I have been paid. The hardest part is because my mindset is already not with this company so subconsciously I would work a lot slower than usual and I know that not as professional as it seems, another issue is I already had performance coaching and my boss already told me the area I need to improve on. I really don't know what I should do in this situation to feel a lot less stressed, anyone who can provide me with some sort of suggestion would be much appreciated.

There are still approximately 2 weeks after I resign I need to serve after I resign (1 week is notice period and 4 working days extra to cover for them paying me a whole month) and I will not feel like working as I felt extremely stressed for the reason I don't really know, anyone has an idea to help me out would be great thank you.

comments.text:
At a former employer - who also espoused "We are a family here ..."   Well, to be honest - it started as a family business out-of-state but grew and at one point "investors" came onboard (meaning the company was no longer family owned).  As the company and its acquisition of "communities" (in the area of seniors) grew and grew; and the expectations - be them staff or directors (management) to then follow these oppressive job descriptions - my department was primarily overtaxed with unrealistic expectations with the powers that be saying:  "Well, this IS the [new normal]!"  Then, after working those grueling and often scary 21 months of Covid-19 / lockdown and pandemic - the appreciation and "reward" for working in a brick and mortar business (there was no "working remotely" for anyone) - they just kept piling on more and more "expectations" - and - then revamped job descriptions, it was ludicrous!!

Anyway, annually the company's headquarters would send around these "anonymous" questionnaires we were expected to complete - the company stated an outsourced agency was conducting these surveys about the company, work / life balance, training, how much you enjoyed your position, being trained adequately, etc. - my point (sorry, there IS one!) ... at the end, you were REQUIRED to select what location (city / state) you worked in otherwise you couldn't exit out of the survey --- what a joke; real anonymous, huh?!?  

P.S.  They have probably had to hire 2 - 3 people to replace me after I resigned ... 🗽

comments.text: Koriander Yander Just providing context, not condoning the act or anything. In the business I'm in, we can't afford to "lose" someone suddenly be it them taking a day off or getting fired. More often than not, someone getting fired has been planned weeks if not months in advance. If you suddenly see someone come into work that does the exact same thing as you do, whether they're there to "help" you or whatever reason they gave you. Odds are you're being replaced or being phased out. The only company that suddenly fire someone without a backup plan is a bad one.

comments.text: Count the red flags in this story! I interviewed for a graphic design position with a Marketing agency. First off, I was told they are a 'start-up' that started 6 years ago.  My first interview question was, "Tell me something that the Biden administration has done that you agree with and something you disagree with." I found this to be an odd question for a graphic design job but tried to answer it as neutral as possible. Before I left, I was given 3 pieces of 'homework' I was to send back to them in a week. They were 3 Marketing tasks like creating a 30 second video ad, logo design, etc. I did them and sent them back. A week later I get a call and am offered the job. I'm told they will send me a contract via email then I can sign it and we can get underway. They send me a contract which is very different from the original job posting. #1. The job is a contract position for 2 months at 25 hours/week vs. posting that said full-time with benefits. #2. Contract is for $15,000/year less than the posting. I called the employer and I was given a story about how they've had some unforeseen financial hiccups and couldn't offer me what the original posting stated. After not budging on my negotiation attempts, I rejected the offer and moved on. Is it over? Not yet...I later learned that the owner (man who interviewed me) is a former lobbyist for the Republican party and hosts his own weekly conservative podcast. So, the political question I was asked absolutely carried weight...for a graphic design job! Remember the homework I had to turn in? Two of my three projects were used months later for real, paying clients! I couldn't help but wonder how many other people they'd done this to over the years of interviewing just to profit off their 'homework.' I learned many things through this process but am so glad I didn't take the job.
comments.author: @g-famflicks7577

comments.text:
"We are family." Can also be a red flag with companies, where they're not placing appropriate boundaries in regards to fraternization or nepotism. 
Meijer says "we are family." I couldn't even get considered for manager training after working my ass off for 3 years there, being the only person who could handle logistics for the store use supplies, etc....but the market director's mom works as a cart pusher for 3 months and gets promoted to deli manager immediately after. I couldn't call what I was doing a "kid's job," because you can't rely on a kid to keep on top of supplies that 100 fucking people use to do their jobs, communicate with management to get extra for sales, all while still fulfilling other duties in the store (mainly stocking and ad set.) That shit right there, though, convinced me that no matter how hard I tried in that place, I wasn't going to be separated from that position. 

I now work for a company that was founded by a duck dynasty-looking guy, and not only do I make like twice as much money doing this shit, it's easier to put up with because my boss has an innate understanding that I'm there for money, and if he wants me to go above and beyond with something, he dangles that carrot in my face, whether it's extra money from him, "generosity" that the customer is offering, or expensive orders that go on my truck instead of the other guy's. He doesn't try the "we are family" bit. "We're a team." We have a common goal of getting the bread and trouncing other stores in the area with customer service.
comments.author: @grumblebuggyspergamatron6466

comments.text: Also have to watch out for the word "flexible." Is it an option or a requirement?

comments.text:
I got turned down by a company that said I checked all the boxes they wanted. Because I had too much experience and was too old. The company was M-TV. Maybe it was a good thing.
But I also did not let them know about every thing I did getting into IT work.  Build swimming pools and a cabanas. Rebuilding engines and transmissions. Operations in a warehouse.
But I did tell them about EW repair and operations without stepping on my TS clearance. Plus the dual Bio-science and electronics degree.
Oh and I did not have a student loan to pay back.
By 2000 in CA I could make more driving a fork lift in Detroit.
 One my bosses that worked for a company that went bankrupt in 1993. Got transferred from LA to Chattanooga in another company holding in 1991.
He was complaining about going from $95,000 to $55,000. I told him they just gave you a raise. Take it.
Yes the Country Club, 40 acres and barn for the daughter's horse was a doable thing in 1991 in Chattanooga on $55,000 with enough left over for mom's new Caddy.
 He told me I was right. When the company sent him back to clean up some issues. Plus sell the house in PV.
I am and was flexible. I also never gave up my side job. It is the only retirement package I get today. That DoD monthly check comes in handy. 
Meanwhile little brother worked for GM for 30 years. He got lucky. He retired in 2006. He also lost 1 million on GM company stock from the employee stock purchase program in 2009. 1m to 0.00. But he does get retirement. From the UAW. He was in the 1st wave of retiring boomers. BTW that funding was transfered from the GM coffers to the union upon retirement.
 There is no such thing as loyalty among thieves and corporations. I have always treated companies the same as they treated me.
 I learned early on to not go at 100% because you don't get promoted. They have to hire two people to replace you. They always pick the most likable one in the middle of the pack.
Yes I got real good at picking up on HR and the company line. I also interviewed about 10,000 seeking access to NSA/Ft. Meade.
 I also pissed of the Provost Marshall by directing and telling the MPs how to handle a situation with getting media attention. Yep someone was running a scam.
 The the base commander asked why I did that. He was happy and the Provost Marshall was not happy about me stepping on her dick. She never understood I saved her career.
Problem is by the time you learn how to deal with all that crap. You are told old to care anymore. Plus I don't need to.

comments.text: Nowadays, it's easy to find out what the local market is paying for your position, so I don't see a "competitive salary" statement to be a bad thing, necessarily. But, as with any buzzword-laden sentence, you have to press them on specifics. "What do you mean when you say that, exactly? Have you compared the salary for this roles with others in the market? Is it better than that? And why is it higher/lower than the average?"

comments.text: Years ago, I was called for an interview and I asked the HR Rep during the call what the rate was. She said it was competitive to other similar employers but didn’t know off hand. I researched before hand so had an idea of +- $1/hour. At the interview after being made to wait 45 minutes to get called, then another 15 minutes for the supervisor to arrive, the interview began. I didn’t want the job anymore so I answered their questions very bluntly. When asked if I had any questions I asked what the rate was. The answer they gave me was “we pay the industry standard”. Again I asked how much, it turned out to be $6.50 less per hour but “we’re a family, and our culture is unique to that” and “money shouldn’t drive your decision”. I walked out without acknowledging them and was super pissed off for having my time wasted. From then on if I ask questions during the initial call I will not accept an invitation interview unless I have all the facts. Live and learn.

comments.text:
That happened to me. The company asked me to create a reporting system. So I did, in two weeks on my $1500 workstation. Then I was told I needed to use a different database because mine "wasn't scalable". I said that was a mistake. The fact the prototype worked great on a full dataset was proof that it was. Nope. So we hired a bunch of specialists to build the system on a different database. I said it wouldn't work on that particular database. The answer was "you're being too negative." Three months later, the team of specialists reaches the same conclusion. Again, I bring up the fact I have had a fully working prototype on an inexpensive computer for months.
Long story short: It took another three months and a another team of specialists working on a multi-million dollar specialized database (wrong kind of database too 😆) and hardware to create a system that was almost as fast as my $1500 workstation. But I was the stubborn, uncooperative one.
comments.author: @rufusmcgee4383

comments.text:
The company I worked 15 years for would constantly ask us for input. For a few years I would gladly voice ideas I had to improve safety and productivity, and nearly every time I'd get shot down and told that my idea wouldn't work.
     And nearly every time, a few weeks later, there'd be new regional directives for improving safety and productivity. And I'd get to read all my "bad" ideas in these emails, being made into policy.
     Finally it hit me that management was getting their accolades off the ideas given them by their employees, while the employees essentially get told they're stupid.
     After that I adhered to a strict mantra; if you have a good idea, KEEP IT TO YOURSELF. Make those lazy management swine actually work to keep their phony jobs.

comments.text:
​ @briandullaghan8375  my former employer has a policy where employee's names were supposed to be printed on the front of their hard hats. They said it was so customers could tell our names. I knew it was so corporate management could pretend to know our names when they'd make appearances at our job sites.
     I thought it'd be funny to put my 10-digit employee number on my hard hat instead of my name. Apparently management didn't see the humor in it. I told them that if any customer wanted to know my name, all they had to do was ask (since most wouldn't see the name printed and would ask anyway). They threatened to send me home for not being a 'team player', and I caved. But after that I had trouble keeping my name on my hat, the adhesive just wouldn't stick. Weird.

comments.text:
1)  There is no company...in the world...that doesn't say some variation of all these things.  Some are considerably more subtle about it, but the concept remains the same.  It's a natural consequence of the profit motive.  It can't be changed so long as profit is the point...and it MUST be the point in a capitalist system.  That will always be its downfall, because it's irrational, and mathematically unsustainable.
.
2)  Knowing your workplace is toxic is like noticing that there is a sky.  It doesn't change anything, and is itself unchangeable.  You'll get the same thing no matter where you go.  The only time it seems different is when you stumble across a company that is more subtle about it, and you're still on that high of "making a change" in your life, and that subtlety eases you more slowly into exactly the same problems you had before...possibly enough that you don't even realize it even when things are actually just as bad, and still feel good about a job that's still treating you like shit.

comments.text: I find a lot of situational questions in an interview tell me a lot about a company's culture and the issues they've had to deal with.  They typically ask these based on issues in their recent past, sometimes with the person you're replacing.  They're the kind of situations that have caused the company grief and they're looking to avoid.  Be mindful of the questions being asked and, if you have a quick-processing mind, question, at least to yourself,  ask why they're asking the question(s).  If the question is something that easily could have been found in the first 15 seconds of scanning your resume, that's a big red flag in my book.  If it's a position at a place you're currently working, unless they know you and your skills, education, etc., it's an even bigger red flag.
comments.author: @wassupinlasvegas9735

comments.text: Something that needs to be added to the "we will promote you later" segment.  After you fight to get the promotion, they will tell you that the pay increase for the new position exceeds the maximum percentage allowable.  So you may end up with the promotion, but you will be working at less than the base salary for the position.  And as all pay increases are a percentage of what you currently earn, your deficit in pay will only compound as the years go by.  If they say they will promote you later, you can be assured that they will NEVER pay you what you are worth.  The only reason to work at such a place is when you desperately need to.  And then concentrate more on finding a new job than you do on learning your current job, as you don't want to be there one second longer than you have to be.  Don't feel bad about that, they are the ones screwing you.

Your commentary was spot on. I once applied to a company that had a weird vibe when I went for the interview. The owner of the company interviewed me. When he asked if I had questions, I asked what a workday was like there—how it "felt" to work for that company. He basically gave the "we work hard, we play hard" answer, but in different words. He said, "Well, people are allowed to enjoy their job, but when it comes down to it, we have to get our work done."

When I asked him what people enjoyed most about their jobs he said he had no idea and that I would have to ask them. He didn't know what his direct reports liked about working there, and I got the impression that he really didn't care.

They didn't call any of my listed references or contact me after the interview. I'm glad I dodged that bullet.

comments.text:
I'm nearing 70. I look back at my life and one of the finest memorable moments was the day in 1985 that I told my boss ''Stick this job in your ass sideways''.  I was 32 years old working for a giant company that claimed to ''Bring good things to life''. Not my life....   They threatened me because I refused to move out of state shortly after buying my first house.  ''Its your job. You go where we tell you to go.''  I resigned right then from the toxic environment with no other job offers. I starved for the next 8 months after forming my own corporation and engineering business until things started rolling.  I paid off my mortgage in 3 years.

Looking back, that spur of the moment decision to resign paid out handsomely. I built my own road, incorporated, and started my own engineering business. That opened the door to buying and operating commercial properties in California and I quit engineering altogether in the mid 90's. It wasn't easy at all being on my own ''working for myself'' but after retiring in 2018 the headaches of running businesses disappeared and are now long forgotten. My buddy retired from the same company. I hear from him every Christmas.  I tell him ''I wish I had a retirement income'' and ''I don't have a 401K'' just so he doesn't feel like he's the only penny waiting for change.
comments.author: @kimmer6

It is important to distinguish "this is a family-owned company, so yeah, a lot of us with similar lastnames are actually family" (which may actually be a very well-managed company [see: Roquette, Mercadona], but you need to remember not to get in the middle when two cousins are arguing) and "I want to be a mother for you!" (sic; our collective response was "I already have one of those and don't either need or want a second one!")

"We'll promote you later"... riiiight. Later Street ends in Never Square (Spanish sentence). "Career path" tends to be similar; often when those exist it is a single one and if you want to do anything else you'll need to move to a different company.

comments.text: "It is what it is", "There's a hundred, thousand, etc, people out there who'd love to have your job", and my personally cringy favorite meeting cliché, "Low hanging fruit"...if you hear any of these commonly said, get out, especially as a group.  The institution is rife with not listening to employee complaints (or worse, using them to leverage more from the employees by "fixing" things in the form of taking things away or some other way to put more responsibility on them), tells them they are lucky, and proceeds to overwork them some more towards a particular goal while ignoring the elephant in the room problems.  Same when they say in job postings "do you like working with cutting edge technology, enjoy a challenge, etc?"... you will be working on products rushed to market with little or no support, and they will expect you to devote the time to sort them out in the field...all while expecting you to jump on the conference call the next morning to hear the first part of this comment.   "Overtime is paid according to fluctuating workweek methodology"= We do not pay time and a half, straight time, or anything else that could be deemed fair wage.  The more hours you work, the less you get paid, starting with half your normal hourly rate. Beware.
comments.author: @timtimtimmay4654

comments.text: Factory “Supervisors” are just the trick ponies of a workplace. They just have a good asskissing record. Soon as they get promoted. They start interrupting smoke breaks by mentioning how poor the company is and how much production needs to step up. No raises. But production gets a guilt trip. The smartest employees only worked there for a couple years after school. Just to get employment history for the better future job. I did a factory till the plumbing shop decided I was reliable and willing to learn. Thank god I got out of there. Retail was worse but the supervisors or shift managers never interrupted a bitch session with “the company is super poor right now “. You want happiness, become your own boss. But first learn how to be an employee.

comments.text:
I know this is what I get for slacking off in school and only being able to work shit kicker jobs but there was a company I used to work for where I my role was washroom services etc. They would continually pile unrealistic workloads on and refuse to pay you any overtime. They hire you on an hourly wage yet refuse to ever pay you over the 38 hour work week. They used the fact that you were able to take the van home every day instead of having to drive your own vehicle to work as an excuse to not compensate you adequately for the work you did. Except, you were required to take the vehicle for servicing etc. More of your own time so that really negated any benefit of being able to use the work vehicle for commuting.

I eventually started putting my foot down and refusing to complete any work after my 7.6 hours in a day was up and left the job in less than a year
comments.author: @peterdonkey-doo8125

comments.text:
One of the more interesting misdirection attempts I saw over salary was where one facility paid everyone significantly more than the others. The misdirect was that they did this not by just paying a cost of living adjustment for location, but by giving people promotions to higher pay grades. So you have a coworker at another locations whose job title and pay is three or four levels above yours, but as far as actual job qualifications, ability, and responsibilities go they are one or two levels BELOW.

The upshot was that grossly incompetent individuals would try to pull rank on you when you caught them screwing up.

comments.text:
My last employer brought me from unskilled high school dropout to running the company for them after 8 short years. I worked for free for them for 9 months to pull through an oil crash in which we were posting losses to keep the company alive. When prices came back and we were still on our feet, they paid off my mortgage as a thank you—3 years’ pay. 

My company has been my family, closer than my family in some ways. I have always treated my company and coworkers like family. Working dangerous oilfield jobs where we place our lives in one another’s hands a dozen times a day and have to trust that everyone else has done their job and that we would risk our lives to make sure none of our children loses their dad that day…you bet your ass we’re a family.

I pity anyone who’s never had that experience or worldview.
comments.author: @mookiewilson4166

comments.text: @mookiewilson4166  Cherish it my friend. It’s a rarity. Most people who are employed don’t have that. I’m watching my company close its distribution center while laying off a bunch of people are redistributing the work, so I could give two shits about those people who I’ve lost all respect for.

comments.text:
Absolutely. I spent 15 years with a company, had numerous positive remarks from customers, a perfect safety record, and good repoire with nearly everyone I've worked with within the company. I was widely known as a really good, hard worker.
     None of that mattered. As soon as I was in a situation where the company could've got my back against some stupid 2022-style empty accusations, they didn't. No, instead they threw me right under the bus. They didn't fire me, but they tried to demote me and force me to do "sensitivity training". I ended up quitting out of sheer disgust.
     Don't waste your time fretting over going the extra mile for your company. The only people they're interested in are the types who wouldn't think twice about stabbing their coworkers in the back to get ahead--and call it "ambition".

comments.text: The companies that promise callbacks from layoffs are employing a losing strategy. I worked as a manufacturing engineer at a union assembly plant. They would hire in a new batch of assemblers and then lay most of them off a few months later. The good ones would immediately go get better jobs and the lazy ones would sit at home watching cartoons until they were called back.. The result being that we had a hard time retaining the good, productive employees, but found that the least productive employees always came back. This is the exact opposite of what you want. I worked at three factories that did this and all three are now vacant lots.

comments.text:
Some of my favorites, which weren't mentioned:

"We're a business in a recession-proof industry" = Terrible sales numbers all the time.  And you think they'll pay you well?  Ever tried squeezing blood from a rock?

"Get paid what you are actually worth!" = Economically impossible.  ALL for-profit businesses operate under the principle of paying you less than you are actually worth.  That's how they are able to pay for things like overhead (utilities, rent, etc.), plus pay the administrative staff, AND have a healthy profit margin to keep their investors/ shareholders happy.  The only trick is finding the companies that pay you the closest to what you are actually worth... not searching for ones who will actually do so.

Also, look at the tenure of the employees who have been around the longest.  If no non-managers have been there more than 5 years, for a company that has been in existence for several decades... guess who's going to be looking for a new job when the 5 year mark comes up?
comments.author: @marcmays48

comments.text:
"Always hiring"
Trucking companies.
I once asked a trucking company recruiter if they got a bonus for drivers who stay a year. He laughed, "I get one if they stay 90 days."
With most trucking companies there's not even an interview, per se.
You send your info to the recruiter who is just checking boxes... license, check... endorsements, check... driving record, check... recent experience, check...
If all the boxes check, it's "when can you come to orientation"... you're hired, pending a urine sample and test drive.
Do they care if you're actually a cool person to work with? Take a wild guess.

Actually, there are some really good companies who rely far too much on "cliche's to communicate with their employees. I recently retired from one of the most profitable airlines in the history of aviation. However, their standard responses to questions, or suggestions by frontline employees went like this..."Thanks for reaching out". "We'll do a deep dive on that, so that going forward, we'll be laser focused, on having your back".
 "Our metrics show us, that we may have to sunset several programs and implement more customer-centric policies, as we apply new best practices, that will surely be game changers".

comments.text:
In my experience, when a company says they're a "fast paced environment" and need someone who can "multi-task", this means there's no work.  
.
Each and every time I've been hired by a company who says that, my first day involves coming in at 9am, sitting down, and doing absolutely nothing until 5pm.  I can't be on my phone, I can't look at youtube, I literally sit and stare at the wall until it's time to go home.  If I ask if there's any work, the supervisors get super annoyed.  Their answer is that I should "just chill" or something similar.  By day 3, I'm walking around in circles, wanting to sweep the floor, looking for excuses to go outside and walk around, trying to get the day to go by, and finally I just quit because I simply can't stand sitting and staring into space for 8 hours.
.
I've run into this problem so many times that I'm no longer certain how capitalism works.  The entire theory is based around people acting out of "self interest" and hiring new people when they need work done.  But this clearly isn't the case.  I've been hired so many times when there was no work, and asking for work gets you dirty looks.  You're paying me money to do nothing.  I don't get it... but I know when I hear the words "face paced" and "multi-tasking" that the job will essentially be sitting and doing nothing until I can't stand it and decide to quit.
comments.author: @validpoint9849

"This is a fast paced environment" and "must be a good multi-tasker"  just means  they are understaffed and expect you to do the work of 2 or 3 people. 

"Must be a quick learner"   means  they aren't going to train you.

"We work hard and play hard"  You are going to be overworked and expected to put in lots of overtime.

"We are an equal opportunity employer"  No,  they're not.

"We accommodate people with disabilities"  No,  they don't.

"We are like family"  They're not your family.  and they will want you to put this job before your real family. 

"We only want the best"   then you better check to see if they pay the best. and chances are,  they don't.

comments.text:
FYI - To those who have not dealt with HR directly, take note that they are there to Protect the company at ALL Cost.  They will do all they can, short of physically slapping you in the face, to either make your complaint go away or have you quit so they don't have to pay you unemployment.  They are in NO WAY there to help you.  Unless you have a CLEAR VIVID Video with 3 witnesses where say your boss is physically abusing you, they will Not help you in any way.

Don't ask me how I know this, just be wise and do NOT trust HR.  At best your situation will remain the same, at worse you will loose your job (NO unemployment income as well)  and any benefits and pension that you once HAD.

It is difficult to work in an abusive and exploiting environment, but tread lightly when thinking of contacting HR for help.  Very few circumstances will warrant contacting HR.  In most cases, you either have to just continue supporting the toxic environment till you can find another job to fall back on when you quit.  Build your skills and resume is key at all times.  Grow your knowledge and ask questions to other others, in and out of your department to improve your value.  The more you know the more likely you can be hired somewhere else and possibly be paid more.

NEVER feel you are Responsible for a company because they will forget you existed 1 hour after they receive confirmation from FTD Flowers that the bouquet of flowers they sent arrived to your funeral-viewing.
comments.author: @JohnPaul-ol5zl

I totally agree with the sentiment that the people that I work with are not my family, nor are they my social group. I tend to disagree with the philosophy some have that it should be. Often uncomfortable relationships will develop in those social settings. Bosses will often get too close to employees in social settings, or employees get overly familiar with bosses and then undoubtedly end up expecting preferential treatment. I've seen it too many times. Also, alcohol is always  a bad idea / mix with the work force. 
When I hear some administrative level person, manager say, " we work hard, we play hard", it's an immediate turn off to me if they're expecting me to join in the social life with them. comments.text: Many times over the years I've had to train myself because organizations have this attitude of "You came to work for us, so you must know how to do everything already."  I'd end sitting in the corner in reading all the manuals, asking questions (which most people won't answer as though I'm taking their jobs.).  I've been written up for taking my time reading manuals and not doing important stuff like cleaning the floors or other busywork (not what I was hired to do).  My last career, I requested training when I first was assigned and was told "Read the book" on a one-of-a-kind system.  I did and some of the language and writing style was so bad, that no normal human being could understand it (I score in the top 5 percent for Reading Comprehension.)  I was criticized for bothering other people (especially engineers) for asking questions.  Later when I took over as a lead technician.  I sat down and read every book, manual, schematic, theory of operation, and then trained every one of my fellow workers to the same level.  I was also lucky to assigned one of the best engineers in the company (who patiently answered when I asked a ton of questions).  We had one of the highest reliability rates of out of all the groups as a well-trained team.  Training is the most important thing any company (military or civilian) can do for its people and it's the most neglected task when a new person hired or transferred in a new section.  It should be considered a criminal act if a company fails to train someone and death/injury/serious property damage occur from that failure.
comments.author: @marks1638

comments.text: I heard all of these phrases at my last company. The place was full of cliques, dangled carrots constantly, and reminded everyone daily that they were replaceable. We constantly were told that we were like family, but when covid hit and signs were pointing to things going south- people were laid off and promised that they would call them when things were back to normal... thing is, once covid hit we got even more busy and we're all forced to wear multiple hats without any increase in pay. We all asked why we couldn't rehire the people they let go or get some more people because we were now doing double what we did last year. They said that because they were a start up business that everything was too tight. They had doubled their yearly income as a company over the past 5 years they had been in business- I learned that they just wanted a select few to succeed if they fit in their clique and would work everyone else ragged by promising promotions and increases in pay. The warehouse manager did all the duties of warehouse manager and was referred to as the warehouse manager for 8 months before they finally gave him the title and the pay raise to go with it. I wish I would have known about these phrases before so I could have looked for another job before accepting this one.

comments.text: Call center jobs/companies are notorious for alot of what you are talking about.  I used to be a supervisor at a call center in central Illinois, and this place was really big on the "hoo rah rah's" and handing out candy bars for little mundane things to try to keep you motivated.  However, the attrition and turnover rate was just horrible.  Behind the scenes, the workforce department was constantly monitoring your phone productivity, and we constantly wrote people up with warnings and "action plans" to coach and discipline the reps.  Then, the KPI metrics were always never realistic for alot of the reps, so alot of people got fired for one or 2 metrics that really didn't break the company.  The point you made about companies saying "we are family", this place did feel like a cult after working there a couple years.  The "carrot on the stick" incentives, same thing there, once you mastered something, those carrots went bye bye and made them very difficult unreasonable to achieve.  I felt awful for being the tool to fire people.  I am glad I got out of that type of company and line of work.  Plus it was very stressful with long hours and being stuck at a computer like 50 to 60 hours a week and it was never good enough for upper management.

comments.text: The company I work for has what's called "employee engagement", which basically means, "We make work as much like a High School" as possible, right down to hand made decorations in the hallway, and dance/karaoke competitions and the like. And yes, we have a foosball table. On the other end of it, they give us a hard time if we need to call out. We're allowed 5 pts before we get coached, we get 1/4 for missing part of a shift (even if we only work 5 min), and 1 whole point if we miss the whole day. And if we hit 5 pts, it's still pretty hard to get fired. You have to really suck. All they wanna know when you call in is "do you wanna use sick/benefit time"? And they frequently offer incentives (prizes, raffles, extra pay) just for showing up for your scheduled shift, and working the whole thing. (I won an Oculus.) They understand that this is just a job for most of us, so seem to go out of their way to make us want to stay. They also get that sometimes, you just don't want to. It's not uncommon to call in and say, "I'm just not feelin' it today." or "I didn't get much sleep last night." As long we don't abuse it, and stay within our points, they're fine with it. Oh and we don't get any points if we use sick time. They're not perfect, but they're generally a pretty decent company.

comments.text: The simple fact that an extremely toxic person was in a management position at that firm clearly indicates the culture of the place. The only law firms where I've seen toxicity (and I've worked at quite a few) had the following: 1)  the administrator was some sort of religious freak, generally an Evangelical Christian, or 2) the firm's corporate headquarters were located in a different state than its satellites. For example, a law firm trying to graft the culture of Dallas, Texas onto the culture of St. Paul, Minnesota. From reactionary to ultra-progressive. That scenario was attempted and did not end well. Minnesota is proud of its many Native American Tribes. Our St. Paul firm received a "gift" from corporate: an enormous statue of a Native man riding a horse, with the inscription "Horse Thief" printed below. And on administrative assistant's day, everyone received a squeezable "stress ball" in the shape of a yellow star.

comments.text:
I think one of the best things to happen to me in my life was losing a decent job with great pay back in 2009. I realized that losing a job, no matter how good you think the job is, isn't the end of the world. Far from it actually.
Now I have absolutely no fear of losing a job, unlike most people I know, and no boss, manager, or company for that matter, will ever walk all over me again.
A prime example was last year when the pandemic was in full swing, the company decided to close for a full week with pay.
Then the company decided that half of my shift would have to come back a day early to start up, with me included. So basically, every employee in the company was getting a full week off with pay except half of my shift.
I just told my manager straight out I won't be coming in on that day. A few others said it too but after threats of disciplinary action they all backed down. I didn't. I told my manager I won't have the piss taken out of me by anyone and that I won't be made an idiot out of.
He backed down and when the list came out of who had to come in, guess who's name wasn't on it?
They only have any power over you when they know you're afraid to lose your job.

comments.text:
@dave7701  Yes, I realize that the 2 weeks notice is for their benefit.  And that is part of my point.  When a company asks me if I 'love' working there, I have to wonder what is prompting the question.  Are they concerned about employee retention?  In that case, perhaps it's more to the point to ask them what employees like (or don't) about working there.

From the company's point of view, the employee is a resource, not an equal partner in the arrangement.  I accept that.  But in that context, for the company to turn around and ask if I "love" working there, it leaves a negative impression.  Business is business, and the implication that I should  emotionally invest in the arrangement is actually a bit insulting.

comments.text:
The last place that hired me had so many red flags...  i was told on the phone that the reason they were hiring me was that i "seemed mature enough to do the job".  Um, i have 20 years experience in that field and three degrees.  Even at the time i thought that statement was very odd.

Then my first day i find out that all three of the people in that position quit or have put in their notice.

Then i find out that they are changing the personnel structure and what i interviewed for is clearly not the job.

Then i find out they really don't know what it's going to look like and I'll be in a supporting role to the person that is part of the new structure.  "We'll provide all the help you need."

I ask for a meeting to discuss the above, i get talked over for half an hour.  Then i get a follow up email telling me that i "have to respect leadership's decisions (which was not part of the discussion and cue Cartman demanding respect for his authoritay).  The best part of the email was the recommendation that i get counseling from EAP... who the fuck does that?

After reading that email, I left my badge on the desk and walked out.  I lasted 3 days.

I spoke up every time and said, "no one has my unique set of talents, skills, education, and experience, NO ONE". After being corrected 3 times in public, the manager stopped saying it. It was horseshit and he knew it. It's kind of like a parrot repeating a phrase without understanding what any of it means. I know it's hard to be the guy with a target on their back, but it is important to always stand up for yourself and do not cater to the status quo. You have to pick your battles and forever remain non-threatening and respectful, but you do not ever have to be a yes-man. If you are expected to be a yes-man: your days are numbered anyway because new leadership always brings with them their own yes-men or want to create their own because the old regime is never what they want...

comments.text:
Just laughing at all the comments below of examples of red flag statements they have seen at their job. So many are spot on.
The one thing that's missing in understanding these statements is this:
The fact that they would SAY that to you, directly, shows how out of touch with reality some of these people have gotten.
Higher Ups in these companies literally have a directive to go around 'Evangelizing' the business to the employees. 
And some of them suck so bad at that amazingly simple job, that they are trying to entice you with statements like 'We are family' which for many, is VERY not attractive.
You are an EMPLOYER. I want you to give me a paycheck and stay out of my life outside that 40 hours a week.
You want me to come to some Team Building thing after hours? NO. Make it during hours if you actually value comraderie.
Otherwise it's not Team Building, its Life Intrusion.
REAL comraderie comes from us becoming friends, and that includes us going and doing stuff OUTSIDE of work hours VOLUNTARILY, and doesn't require management scheduling it.
Just STAY OUT of my personal time. You get the MAJORITY of my life, already.

comments.text:
I have used "everyone's replaceabke" as a boss. However, the handful of times I did use it, we were in a serious "write up" level situation and dealing with a younger employee or newer manager who, for one reason or another, felt as if they were irreplaceable or untouchable. The phrase was intended to remind people that they are not untouchable and need to correct their behavior. 

Hence, it is a fine scalpel, not a blunt instrument. If it is a general phrase/blunt instrument, though, I agree that it is a sign of toxic corporate culture.

comments.text:
if you want a promotion, look for opportunities to demonstrate the skills/abilities of the role you want, instead of doing your current role better. if you want to be a manager, demonstrate leadership. Find ways to improve the way the team works, mentor the newer members and help them get up to speed, ect, ect. Either you'll get promoted, or you'll develop the skills to get the promotion elsewhere.

doing your current role better in hopes of a promotion signals that you could have been working harder before you heard about the opportunity, and only apply yourself when you think theres a prize around the corner. it says that once you get the promotion, you'll go back to your old level of effort. its better to pace yourself and work at a sustainable level of effort over the long term.
comments.author: @anthonyskrzypczak9437

In a sense you are right but partially. If I did get the cook job, I definitely would've just stayed in the scope of my job. That doesn't mean I would work less hard, it just means I would stop spreading myself out between other positions.

comments.text: I am a dinosaur!  No longer will you get a pension or severance.  If you get laid off on economy downturns resulting in low demand, you no longer get severance or extended benefits to hold you over until you are called back and you are no longer guaranteed to get called back and if you do, many times you start at day 1 with lower pay and benefits and forget utilized unused vacation time.  These jobs do not exist.  Give no employer layalto and get a better job as soon as possible and always have a plan B.  Jump ship at the slightest sign of uncertainty.  The company is not loyal to you so go for anything better when it comes up.  A 2 week notice, NO.  And NEVER tell your employer where you are going, they will F you on a reference!  Look out for you and yours, not your employer!  They will never look out for you!  I am blessed to be retired!!!  Thank the Gods!!!  Blessings to all!!!
comments.author: @martinenglish6641

comments.text:
I can top stupid for going back to a company that laid you off... company I was working for kept doing horrible layoffs with no notices or announcements.  It was after a merger, they were eliminating redundancy, the over all business was contracting, so they needed to jettison bodies.  I say horrible because instead of doing it all at once and reassuring the remaining employees they will still have jobs... it was done quiet like, on the sly... so it was water cooler talk 'Yeah, did you hear about the Accounting department in Lubbock?  They let everyone go'... so that was how you'd hear.  Or you'd contact someone for something... and then find out they, and their entire department are gone.

So seeing the writing on the wall, I started looking for another job.  Got one, left before I got laid off.  But I said this was MORE stupid didn't I?  See, I went to work for a startup.  'We are like a family' and 'we work hard and play hard'.  I was concerned going to work for a start up, and I brought it up in the interview, to leave a job for a start up is risk.  At that point, I got a bald faced lie about their financials.  The business owner was lying to everyone about the funding he had.  Company goes tits up after about 4 months.  Severance?  I had to fight to get 75% of my last paycheck.  We are not talking unpaid vacation days, we are talking hours actually worked.  I could have sued for treble damages and won easily... but ever collect from a dead company?  So after losing that job, I got a good contract gig that lasted a year... when the year was up, another former employer talked me into coming back, not the company who's layoff I ducked, a different company.  I was hired for one job, then they threw me into another 'temporarily'... and a year later I still hadn't worked the job I was hired for... so I went BACK to the company that almost laid me off 2 years prior... they contacted me... they begged me to come back... 

So I did.  And got laid off 14 months later.  So, I was so stupid that I successfully dodged a huge layoff, was even told by my old boss which layoff would have gotten me (I had about 4 more months, more than I thought, but not much)... only to come back two years later... and get laid off.

STUPID
comments.author: @voodoochild1975az
