comments.text: I worked for a company back in the 90's and the president of the company was a crook.  He did not pay income tax for years ($189,000+) and the IRS put a lien on the company.  Employees were getting paychecks written on closed accounts or the bank account did not have the funds.  The company wrote the building manager over $90,000 worth of bad checks and I was shocked that criminal charges were not filed.  When the company had to lay off employees, the president told the employees that the last day was the coming Friday and that they did not have to come in on that Wednesday and Thursday.  Many employees did not show up on those days and when they applied for unemployment, the president told the unemployment office that the employees were a "no call, no show."  Those employees were denied unemployment benefits.  I showed up until that Friday and the office manager was calling me into her office about 6 to 10 times berating me.  Her plan was to try to get me to quit, but I didn't.  I got my paycheck and you guessed it, it was written on a closed account.  I went out for unemployment and found out that the company never listed me as an employee, unemployment was denied.  The company went out of business and left the building in the middle of the night.

comments.text: I used to work at a really bad company. The sad thing is they thought they were an amazing company. They were really good at even tricking people into believing it. It was almost cult like. Took me 4 years of suffering before I had the courage to leave.
comments.author: @MuddinNYC

comments.text: How did you start to realize it wasn’t good ? How did they trick people?
comments.author: @user-iu3cy2tx3c

comments.text: @user-iu3cy2tx3c  They used words like we are family. They made you feel like you were worthless and they were doing you a favor by keeping you employed. They did it in an indirect way. They would also offer free snacks or drinks. Sounds like a great thing until you realize it was just to keep you working in the office longer. They could justify lower pay by saying hey you get free stuff. They would give swag away so you slowly begin to identify yourself with the brand. They would limit your time outside of work by doing happy hours after work and free meals so you didn't spend time with real friends or family. They would make it sound like they were going to be the next Google or apple. Irl they were just the next wework. There are other things but these are some things that looking back should have been obvious it's a bad company. I realized when my father died. I wanted to take time off. Officially we had unlimited vacation but when I tried they denied me because we needed to ship to our biggest customer. I never took vacation for 2 years but the exec and management took 3 weeks off every quarter. Than Covid hit and the entire executive team was wfh but the engineers were told to go in everyday because we are to critical to allow to wfh. Finally I had the courage to leave when I asked my non crucial coworkers how much they made. I found out they work 2 hours a day but made 3x my pay. In fact all the engineers left shortly after. They all woke up from the cult. Sadly they are still in business. They recruit only right out of college for engineers so you feel a blind loyalty to them from the start. Anyone who works for a real company would know right away to turn tail and run.
comments.author: @MuddinNYC

comments.text: @user-iu3cy2tx3c  you have to take off rose colored glasses and see the warning signs of a bad company....start an exit plan at the first sign because it wont get better...

comments.text: One of the most laid back jobs that I ever had and I still don't know how they managed to actually function was in a call centre. They are still going but it was off the wall. No one really knew what was going on, who was working etc. They dealt with customer complaints just by telling you what the customer said and that was it. Back you go to work. No blame. No reprecussions. No try not to do it that way again. On my days off they'd always ring to see if I would come in for a few hours so obviously no roster planning. Again, on days off they'd ring and say something like ''I know you were meant to be in at 9 but we'll forget about that if you can do an extra hour at the end of your shift''. I'd say ''I'm not rostered today''. They'd be silent and then say ''Oh yeah! I was looking at the wrong day. Sorry about that''. Finally, one night I was there working the nightshift and at 2am one employee went home sick. The manager on call, yes no manager in the actual building, text me to ask if I was awake and if so could I come in to the office as someone has gone home sick. I replied saying I was currently in the office working and he replied saying ''Thanks for letting me know''. It baffles me how they are still going.

Boy oh boy, do I ever hear you on that my brother!

One of the best things about being retired is no longer having to show up at company social functions like picnics and holiday parties. I freaking HATED company holiday parties with a passion yet I couldn’t get out of going to them at my last employer because I was on the senior staff (yea, big whoop de do!). Why would I want to be forced to give up a Saturday night to socialize with the people I am already around 40 hours a week? I mean, give me a freaking break!!

The way I would cope with these work parties was to get stoned in my car in the parking lot of the party venue since I don’t drink alcohol. Being high on MJ made it much easier for me to pretend like I was having a good time though there was one instance where a female coworker mistook my cannabis infused friendliness for romantic interest and resulted in a somewhat sticky situation that I had to do some fast talking to get out of.

comments.text: The tactics companies use to NOT give pay raises seem to get more transparent and manipulative every year.  I recently found out that new hires at my job now make a higher salary than I do despite me having a higher degree, position of supervision, and 2 years experience.  The reason I can’t just leave?  Student loan assistance must be immediately repaid in full upon termination or resignation a full year after the LAST assistance payment.  Needless to say, my loans are getting fast tracked, I’ll be applying elsewhere for higher pay after 2.5 years, and then they’ll either up my salary or I’ll go get a new one.  I understand a good corporate tactic, but it’s pure poison to give no incentive for advancement to higher roles and hold people hostage to loan “assistance.”

comments.text: I worked for an employer that hired me for a sales position, but I wanted the tech job. I was told the sales job would get my foot in the door, and when a tech job opened up, I would be considered for it. I never was. The metrics for the sales job kept moving all over the place and the goalposts were also constantly moving for the tech job. I was asked to do a job in addition that wasn't part of my job, they refused to change my schedule to accommodate the long-term seasonal job I told them about in the interview, and they just laid everyone off on the spot one day. I put in my two weeks notice a few months before that, but was shown the door immediately when I did. Then they tried to refuse to pay my unemployment, but I gathered a bunch of proof the day before I gave my two weeks notice, so I got unemployment. They were also eventually a defendant in a class-action suit. Terrible company.

comments.text:
"You're replaceable."  I had a new boss who played that G-d Almighty bit during a staff meeting.  He basically told us that it was his way or no way because he was the boss.  "If you don't like it, there's the door."  Which I would have supported if anything he was doing made sense. We were excited to have new blood in our office, because the previous leadership had grown stagnant and they kinda stopped caring because they were close to retirement.  But this guy came in and kept in place everything that was broken and wrecked things that worked.  Morale tanked.

Good employees got up and left because they couldn't take it anymore.  The thing of it is, when a jackass of a boss tries to tell you that you're replaceable, if you're worth your salt you can rightly tell them, "So are you.  I'll have no problem leaving this position and having my talents benefit someone else.  Good luck, pal."

comments.text:
The "we are family" one reminded me of a company my ex worked for.  And I thought it was stupid for a variety of reasons. It was even on their website that they are a "family".
1. His employees would often still be working, long after he went home (as if it was THEIR company).
2. The owner got WAY too far into the employees personal business. Made things weird and messy.
3. He basically forced his employees to spend "quality" time together once a week, to help their "family bond"... Like, dude... THEY HAVE ACTUAL FAMILIES! Let them go HOME! You already spent more time at work, than you do at home... So this was insane to me.

Eventually everyone left, and new hires dwindled. They are no longer in business.
 
There is more, but those stood out the most.

The Rockstar thing made me laugh, because I worked for a company that did that... It was so stupid. "We are looking for a Rockstar...". No. Just no. They were a small company, that did the layoff thing you mentioned. While they didn't say we were a family, they acted like we were all supposed to care about the company as much as they did. Like their baby  was ours. No. I will do my job, and kick ass at it. But, I'm not gonna act like YOUR company is mine. It's not. This company is a long story, but they were the most toxic place I worked for. 

Sorry for the ramble, lol.
comments.author: @scanlonsocial5136

comments.text: Managers are usually the weak point in hiring. Not all companies have hiring managers. And most of the time the left hand isn't communicating with the right. So there's dissociation. How to overcome it? Arrive VERY early and pay attention to what's happening. See what's going on in interactions. So, if you're interviewing with a non-hiring manager and the atmosphere you've witnessed is very much less than stellar, walk away. Or negotiate for more and/or the terms you require.
comments.author: @WiPri0371

comments.text: UPDATE : I worked for a customer service call center company for a month and left. They were - and are - very nice and polite people across the board. But they only pay lower midrange for that work. Benefits are very limited (no medical, retirement). They used the phrase "We are like a family" quite often. They wanted to press me into things I purposely avoided in submitting applications/my resume, namely insurance. I jumped ship only after I tried to hold it out to see just how it would go, even explaining it to my trainer before heading to HR. She helped and didn't help across 2 conversations across 2 consecutive days. In the first, she said she understood, didn't want either to commit to anything right then but wait until the next day, then said in the midst of telling something else that they have no control over what campaigns come their way (tempering the water only to turn the heat back up later on). The next day she was all understanding and what not. She pre-empted my speaking by saying she had something she wanted to tell me first; That all the project managers and at least one client did not want me to leave, that they liked my work on their respective campaigns. Even that my trainer had me labeled me as one of her "superstars". She was willing to take me off the insurance, but i remembered what she said the day before. I do not like insurance at all. Because I've known for at least a decade what's involved and want nothing to do with it. What she told me the day before set the stage for no choice later on. So I exercised my choice to not go back. Because I did such a good job with it, she said they would hold the door open for me if ever I wanted to return. What I gathered from it all was a recognition of my abilities that even I didn't understand. Until now. I got it quick, and they recognized that. Now I do too. A new skill set, because I learned MUCH in that amount of time.

comments.text: Back when I was 22 years old I got my first factory job!! The hours sucked (usually 14 hours a day) and the pay was a complete joke (at the time in 1987 I was earning just $3.55 an hour)!! The overtime pay DID help afford my a new car....but I was living in a lousy single room apartment that had cockroaches thanks to my filthy neighbors!! It was the cheapest place I could find to live that was actually near my job, that I could actually afford on my income though!!! I had worked there nearly 5 years (I started in 1986) and it was a family run company, ran by a husband and wife team, who acted like they were "everybody's friend"!! But more than once I overheard them talking smack about some employee, and they'd randomly just fire people at times without any logic to why they would!!! In fact they had fired FOUR plant managers in the time I worked there! And they had changed everybody on the engineering staff at least twice as well!! And the owner of the company would constantly talk down to people even degrade them openly on the floor in full view of anybody in the shop often enough!! The day I had quit though, they had spent three months attempting to write me up for work I was basically FORCED TO DO by them!! And I was in a "Damned if I do, Damned If I don't" position because I feared for losing my income!! But for the last three months I was under orders from the company themselves as I said....so I just did what I was told when I was told to do it!! THEN the morning I quit I realized something!! I realized I had came to this job looking for work.....so I left this job looking for work!! I had just punched in at the time clock too......so I know it kind of shocked them when I punched back out, and headed to the door!! Oddly that same day I applied at the first temporary agency I passed by on my way home!! They offered me $5 an hour starting pay which was better than what I was earning anyhow!! So I accepted it....sadly nearly five years later I was still working for $5 an hour though, and still living in the crap hole apartment!!

comments.text:
At some point your skills start talking for itself. I no longer apply for jobs, nor accept this kind of BS. If I get laid off due to a downturn, I either do some easy independent contractor work that fit my life schedule, or otherwise take advantage of the free time for general life improvements. I do not, never ever, spend my time applying for jobs. Sooner or later that job comes to me, i get an offer. And being that im already content, not desperate, I tell them what minimum offer I will accept. If they dont want that, well fine. I dont need them that badly either.

Companies who advertise job openings are basically looking to have a pipeline of suckers available they can take advantage of. Serious employers will seek out the best fit for the position, and compensate accordingly. Its all about making due without an employer. If you can do that, your job offerings will be far better.
comments.author: @Santor-

comments.text: I was poached by a retail company to a state manager's level. No position description, no job details - basically just a job title. I was making a 50% salary increase & working 2 hours less per day.  I was excited as there was a bonus up to 15% annually. Slowly the truth merged as I learned the last bonus was 5 years ago & it seemed to be a dog's breakfast as the fraud was rife. 6 months we were bought out & slowly stores were closing as sales bonuses were paid for non-existent new customers. A random stock check by me showed a few boxes of bricks - meaning the contents was stolen. I was firing staff left right & centre until my boss + myself were let go - with no warning.

comments.text:
I've experienced the "we are family" nonsense in several jobs. That's the stupidest thing anyone in a company can tell me. I've never bought into that garbage from people I work with, some of which I can't even stand. Later when they show their true colors, I use it against them ("Is that how you treat your family?" "You know, the family thing goes both ways." and my favorite, "Oh, now after this we're family?"). Also the "we wear a lot of hats" nonsense is the biggest sign of the place being a mess.

I'd also add when companies tell you "we're friendly". I've never ever had the need to clarify to people that I am friendly, and I've never ever met any friendly person who have to say that they are friendly, so if the company has to tell people, chances are the place is a gossip/drama ridden place, infested with all kinds of dysfunctional people who are not friendly at all.

comments.text:
Only once have I heard "We're like a family" and it was partially true. They would send out emails if requested to maybe keep someone in our prayers if they were having a hard time (I'm agnostic but it was a nice gesture. I live in the deep south so I'm a unicorn here, lol), or if someone was struggling financially with something, they might raise awareness to help donate to help out. This could be funeral costs for someone's loved one, a baby shower...or the burial cost to help a woman who had a miscarriage. It was all optional and private if you did donate and it wasn't every week we were being hit with someone's plight, but I did like that they did that. 

However, this was also a job I hated greatly because the owner worked with very unsavory companies, companies that maybe were not illegal but very immoral and unethical. This was a call center and they also made us do political calls, which was not informed to us (at least not me) during the interview. If some politician rocked up and threw down the cash (usually one I did not support), we had to do calls for them. I really wish I would've openly said something but I needed the job at the time. This indeed was a job with a high revolving door and when I finally quit, they were begging us to please refer people there. Fuck that, nobody deserves the stress of that place (or any call center, really, but especially a call center where you take calls for unsavory companies, thus being yelled at all the time by upset customers).

comments.text: Back in the 1970s in Miami, I saw a job listing in the newspaper, I could not resist. I know BS when I step in it, but I was just blown away by the ad and had to meet the man (who had the kahunas to blow that much smoke) and hear the scam. " Swim, surf, ski, and play golf 3 days a week $200. No high school diploma, no background check. All applicants hired." It was door to door sales, and if you could sell the quota in 4 days, you got 3 days off. (counting sat and sun) and you could swim, surf, ski and play golf ! The man was a genius, we became good friends. He trained his sales people with imaginative sales/entertainment skits like "may I clean your toilet for no charge or obligation?" then after a quick brushing, I can keep this toilet clean for 4 months for $5, would you like that? A yes meant they got a toilet bowl cake hung in the tank ! Many people were so amused that they would listen to more of these routines, knowing full well that they were BS.

Here is one my current company told me for years... "We don't have defined salary bands because we want to be able to pay people more if they deserve it." I learned the translation for that was... "We win bids by under valuing our labor costs and having no salary bands means we don't have to level set anyone EVER." 

Also in regards to the comment on the laying people off... Our company laid folks off and then brought back people at a lower salary for a new account (that they underbid the competition by under valuing labor) and told the employees it was take this new salary or turn in their resignations. They did this with other accounts in the company ready and willing to take those folks back at original salary. 

My last day there is October 1st! Onward to a 19k raise and better company!

comments.text:
What when you and your boss aren't at the same (let's call it) wavelength?
- Whenever I feel my week was very productive, my boss interprets it as unproductive...
- Whenever my boss thinks my week was productive, I see it as an unproductive waste of time...

My boss wants everything the quick and dirty way, the faster he sees results the more productive he interprets my week. In reality the faster I deliver results, the more work I've to redo during unpaid weekends and evenings to prevent a spectacular binary meltdown. I've explained this multiple times only to be ignored repeatedly, at one point he even threatened my job.

If it wasn't for the specific type of work I could do at set company, I would've left a long time ago. I'm sadly starting to feel lack of motivation recently.

comments.text: I have always been in luxury sales and design before I retired. I still do design and sales consulting ( because I love teaching people how the right product with the right client is so great) on a contracting basis, and was asked to interview with a ‘start-up’ to get their core product line (fashion accessories) tight. The 2 founders used almost every line you’ve put here. I could’ve cared less to get the gig or not, so I told them the pool table and frisbee golf outings and “team building picnics” were a waste of my time as they don’t bring in or keep clientele. The “work hard play hard” are separate entities. If I can’t get my work done in a day, I need an assistant. If I’m expected to go bowling with my coworkers and management, I expect to be paid. They were 5 years in. The 2 founders had ZERO background in sales, design, fashion, or manufacturing. Yup, 2 mba’s with background in finance and business law. They just wanted to get big enough so a bigger company would buy them out.  Surprisingly, they offered me the job, but at 1/3 less than I contract for as they were a ‘start up’.  Solid Nope. 2 years later and they’re importing cheap knockoffs from China, nothing high fashion. Struggling to stay above water. And they always are running ads! Smh

comments.text: I resigned from my job of 21 years last week.  I'm an ICU & ER RN having saved thousands of lives with my skills in the past 2 decades.  I've gotten one raise in the past 5 years of 50¢ an hour.  I've been told by my supervisor "but we frequently supply donuts and snacks."   In ICU I should have only 2 patients on ventilators, with Covid I've had up to 12.  This past 1.5 years has been a devastating workload for all healthcare workers.  I made $41. an hour but they pay part time travel nurses $160. an hour and I train them.   I'm currently taking a break, sleeping in, watching movies and ordering pizza.  I may become a travel RN, too, but down the road.  There is no end in sight with the massive patient load in hospitals.  If I do become a high paid travel RN I will definitely require a staffing ratio for patients.   People, stay safe, health care workers are leaving constantly, soon there will be few to take care of you.

comments.text:
Cheers to you ... a Front Line worker!   Good Lord you deserve a well deserved break!   A "traveling RN" sounds much better - especially if your life, family situation / responsibilities can handle it ... go for it - when the time is right!

I recently resigned as a Director in a senior living community; grueling for 21 mos (no "working from home) --- I left a much longer comment in this video or perhaps it was another one about working through a pandemic.  My position couldn't even compare to what you and your colleagues have endured in hospitals across the country / the world ... but somehow it's this ongoing expectation to just keep going, work more hours and be expected to take on more and more unrealistic and ever growing job descriptions!   Finally, enough was enough ... they have probably had to hire 2-3 people after my departure / resignation to keep that department afloat ~ 
Anyway, enjoy your downtime and select a new position with more pay, better benefits and more respect - as I too plan to do!  🌠

- "work hard / play hard" - In my experience, usually means they'll work you to death like you said, AND the 'play hard' will be them expecting you to show off your 'glamorous life' that you've achieved by working for them... even though you don't have an ounce of energy to do anything after work. OR they'll have company "events" that are either exclusionary, or so lame it's just lip service.

comments.text: One of my favorites is, “We’re looking for someone who can think outside the box”. What they are really saying is that their company is broken and they are looking for someone to blame it on. Remember, they created “the box”. If they are looking for someone to think outside of it, they are essentially saying that the system they created doesn’t work. Rather than admitting they have lost control, they hire someone to use as a scapegoat. The new hire lasts a few months and then is let go. The management blames the new hire for screwing up the whole company and they pat each other on the back for getting rid of them. They then go back to their business as usual.

comments.text:
"We work hard and we play hard." - sounds like a bunch of douche-bros run the place, so expect some light sexual harassment, crude innuendos, and a general 1950s frat house atmosphere - with eventual lawsuits and/or labor board investigations in their future.

"We are like family." - if your family is dysfunctional, abusive, engages in petty fraud, lies to you, and basically expects you to work like an indentured servant, while the true and actual blood relatives in charge of the business reap all the rewards.  No thank you.

"You are replaceable." - is really an invitation to send out resumes and get a better job, because guess what, the people you work for can also be replaced by a different group.

Also, if their benefits package is below the industry average (for a business of that size and age), avoid that place.  Medical, dental, PTO, sick days, and 401(k) are important and if the company is going super-cheap on these items it means they are having cash flow issues, or are run by folks looking to squeeze out every cent for themselves.

Worked for an Amazon warehouse.  One lady came in to talk about various garbage or other and she reminded us "Remember, Amazon does not need you."  I was speechless...which is a rare thing.

I guess she thought that would make people stop complaining the malfunctioning and suboptimal equipment constantly creating extra needless work, skyrocketing quotas, growing work shifts (when many of us signed on because of the 'flexible scheduling' which was now gone) and increasing micromanagement by managers who had no common sense and orders from higher up that demanded we do a great number of things functionally backwards to appear to be meeting high per-hour rates, despite how much we had to undo and redo at the end of the shift.

Madness.  So much extra work for nothing.

Nobody else wants to train and hardly anybody gets cross-trained on different machines after I got there. Our night shifts are 12 hours and I haven't sat down since Monday. comments.text:
"We'll promote you later."

I took a job where in the verbal offer this was stated with details of how I would be promoted within 6 months and be paid what I was making at my previous job (I took a large pay cut to take this job in a desperate move to exit another toxic work environment). However, in my written offer the promotion was nowhere to be found. I accepted because it was a small company, in the production world even DECENT jobs are difficult to find, and they brought it up periodically to remind me they hadn't forgotten.

Three days after I started my hiring manager and direct supervisor walked out (too long of a story to post here but he wasn't an angel in the scenario either). He and I were the only two in the department. So I worked there for 16 months with no training, garbage pay, garbage benefits, and all because I expected them to do the bare minimum as adults and hold up their end of the bargain.

What I'm saying is don't work for a stone fabricator in Madison, WI. Companies like this need to be ousted.

Ironically I left that job and started working at a place...with a foosball table.

comments.text: I would defend myself at work by admitting I could not "multitask." I explained that I could switch tasks but the more tasks I had to constantly switch between, the less I'd be able to actually accomplish on any of those tasks. I'm no computer, just a simple human being. I once had more than 30 tasks and projects on my plate, and the manager I was assigned to work for wasn't seeing enough progress on "all" of them. I asked which of these 30 items was "priority 1." She insisted that they all were. I replied that you need 29 more people like me if they are all to be done now. I can have several priority 1 tasks and "task switch" as work needed to be done on those urgent projects and tasks. But 30? @timmedlock4402  a Stanford study showed that the human brain is NOT designed to "multitask". And anyone claiming that they're great at multitasking is lying. Better to do one thing at a time and get it right, so you can move onto the next task, instead of having to go back and correct mistakes made during the attempted multitasking. While I spent over 15 years as a data entry operator (with a keystroke speed of 196/minute), I knew that speed without accuracy is a waste of my time and everyone else's. 

The last company I worked for got bought, and complete, accurate data became a thing of the past. High numbers were more important than accuracy, and the other departments that had to deal with our pithy data hated us. Management didn't care--the high numbers were more important to them so they could keep their jobs (and take credit for my work). When it was dictated to us that we had to "make friends" with our co-workers (most of whom were back-stabbers) and we were required to attend the company picnic (held in our black topped parking lot in July with no shade--I called in that day), that did it. It was a relief to leave that dump (which eventually got shut down by the company that bought it).

comments.text:
Start-ups are gambles. They will test one's repertory of abilities and ability to learn. You might find a talent that you didn't think that you had. Even so, the secret of economic success is specialization even if one needs a wide variety of talents. There are stories of people who started on the assembly line or as janitors and became executives, which would never happen in a business with an entrenched bureaucracy. Specialization is growth, and the higher that you go in a bureaucracy (to a point) the more you will specialize. 

Obviously you hope that they replace your janitorial duties that are about two hours a week!

comments.text: Lowering expectations is a function of communication– customers aren’t even always part of the equation. Any time a company expects to not be able to fulfill a promise or estimate, they generally communicates that to people who need to know. That’s lowering people expectations. For example, if a publicly traded company expects to do worse than its initial outlook, it sends out a report telling shareholders to expect that. If employees expect to have steady employment and the company is running into financial trouble, most will tell their employees in advance that they will be conducting layoffs. Look up the word “lowering” and then look up the word “expectations” and then try to figure out how in the world your comment makes sense. It doesn’t. You’re just being deliberately obstinate.

comments.text:
​ @AV57  You've said nothing you didn't say in your first comment. You're just adding bluster to the same glib, hyperbolic, frankly ridiculous statement about reducing expectations— a fundamental concept in any business environment from selling candy out of a dirty basket to managing a Fortune 500 company. To say otherwise is ridiculous. I gave self-evident real-world examples.

Amusingly, I did work in management some time ago. Doing so, I learned that when someone starts rattling off their qualifications they aren't trying to convince me they know what they're talking about, they're trying to convince *themselves*, and they don't even realize it. 99.9% of the time they follow it up by talking straight out of their outbox— because that's the only time anyone needs to boost themselves up like that. If they're confident, they just present actual verifiable evidence, generalizable examples, or lock-tight reasoning. Everything else is just empty words and posturing. Sure— puffing up your chest and making noise makes you feel big. To everybody else, you look exactly the same size— just a lot more ridiculous. 

But hey, I don't know your struggle. If you have a burning need to go on the internet and be homespun YouTube comment business expert then go for it. I've got actual things to do, and I'm far past the age where I feel the need to tickle someone random Dunning-Krueger case's walnuts when they're on a tear, so I'm just going to leave it at that.
comments.author: @andythebouncer

comments.text:
@andythebouncer  your examples are not self-evident. I was speaking on corporatism as the philosophy it is today. Are there outliers? Sure… not every single corporation is ran by corporatists. If you’d like to point out the outliers then feel free to; I won’t object to it, but it doesn’t discount my original claim that corporatism (the dominant philosophy amongst C-level American executives) are under the delusion that perpetual growth in spite of nearly any outside factors must be preached. And I particularly intended to imply that this is directed at store level employees’ performance. No amount of external factors is cause for allowing employees making near minimum wage to become less productive. Instead, what’s communicated down the chain is that cuts to labor hours will put added pressure to those who remain. While short-term expectations may lower, it is always with the express intention of retooling for a quick growth within a matter of a year or two at most. 

I’ve no idea why you went on that personal attack tirade. Maybe you should learn some breathing techniques.
comments.author: @AV57

comments.text:
What I usually do (in the interview process) is ask my potential boss (who is interviewing me) one question: from a business practice perspective in delivering work which two things do you demand of your employees; fast, cheap, or stable?  Which two?  If they get all indignant and say they expect all three I usually just shake their hands and say this is not the job for me because any manager that knows anything about managing will tell you, you can only have two.  At that point they will just point at the door and tell me to get out or whatever (if they are prideful) OR if they really want me and realize they blew it, they might try and backtrack a bit and recover from their horrible answer.

A good company will demand only two of those things from you: cheap fast work (that is not good work), cheap good work (that takes a long time to deliver), OR fast good work (that tends to be very expensive for the company.)  A good company will prioritize.  If they can't (or have never thought of this triangle) then they are probably a bad place for employees to work.

comments.text:
If a hiring manager says that, it means they want to hire someone who is already experienced doing that job or a very similar job.

That's not expecting miracles, it's expecting the perfectly mundane.  If not, then you're not the right candidate.

Some jobs you can afford to have a new hire go through growing pains and some jobs you can't.  A good hiring manager knows what they need and is honest about it.

Just be sure that if you are the right candidate, you're getting paid like the experienced, competent person they're asking for.  No "trainee" pay for non-trainees.

comments.text:
A rather flippant response that I will have to try is "But why would I want to work for a company like this if I was a rockstar? Think about that for a bit, Mr./Mrs/Ms Interviewer: why would I give up playing kick-ass headbangers and shredding solos in front of sold-out arena crowds numbering in the tens of thousands for obscene amounts of money to work for this company, which won't offer even a tenth of the pay potential. I mean, in a few years of blasting out everyone's ears, I'd have enough money to BUY this company if I was a rockstar. comments.text: "We're like a family" is one of the most toxic tropes in the workplace in my opinion and it needs to stop. It sets up an expectation to devote yourself to people that don't deserve your loyalty and have no practical way to compensate it. Companies really CAN'T be like a family for the simple fact that in a family you have to accommodate everyone and you can't fire anyone! Families are way harder to manage which is why your energy needs to go to your real family.

comments.text:
While in many cases this can lead to a toxic environment, I would say it doesn't always. My workplace feels like a family in a sense, and we do all go out of our way to help each other out & get things done. It can mean staying late, it can mean coming in on a day off, but we aren't forced to and we do it out of pure desire to help each other out. It has led to a very positive work environment, because we're always helping each other get things done. I know if I help you when you need it, you'll help me, and  vice versa. 

This doesn't work in most instances however because a lot of people don't care for their jobs.

comments.text:
@progamermoves3957  second the soft skills. I transitioned into IT. Before that I was retail for 14 years, three of those were management. Then I went to Japan to teach English for 8 years.

I think that level of adaptability plus my people skills were what got me hired. I’ve been the unofficial tech guy at most of my previous jobs, but had no real experience.

I ended up with a company where they had to teach me the software anyway, and they told me that soft skills are things that aren’t easily learned. I’ve always had them.

Big advice from an older guy. Learn the difference between winning the battle and winning the war. Sometimes swallow your pride, but don’t be a pushover. It’s a tight balancing act, but should take you far.

comments.text:
"We're like family" 
Me, from a dysfunctional family: So, I'm going to hate 90% of you because you're genuinely terrible people? (My company actually says they're like family, but they're not actually horrible? But it's definitely like family, I genuinely dislike some of them because they're garbage people and garbage at their job, so there's that.)

"You're replaceable"
But it's going to be harder to train someone without the SOPs in my head that none of you bothered to write out because I had to make shit up as I went due to your incompetence, so that'll be fun for you to figure out how to train someone because I won't be there for it. 

The layoff part:
GM laid off a bunch of employees in the early/mid-80s at my mom's plant. She went out to Cali with her friend and met my dad. She didn't go back because I was born. 10/10 for that lay off.
comments.author: @Vinnehkins

comments.text:
My old company, for year after year would tell us how GREAT our group was doing, how well our product was selling, how excited they were in the future. 

Then, apparently, they got some new numbers back from accounting, and they started laying off employees.  And despite the fact that the sales team had gotten a lot of the specific praise previous, the first target was about half the sales team.
I was already on the job-search. Got another round of layoffs shortly before I got my offer, and they assured us that THIS was the last round....
I found out even more people were let-go after I left.

Never believe them when they say it's the last round of layoffs.
